text: Didn't know what to expect. I was in Rogers Park and my friend said let's go to Susie's and check it out. He had never been there either. 5 tables and a small two person counter. We sat down at a small two top table. Susie asked us to move so a single person could sit there and motioned for us to move to a bigger table. No big deal. I had the Bulgogi omelette and my friend had the Bulgogi and Kimchi omelette. Have to say for a one woman operation, the food came timely and Susie knows how to plate a meal. The food is very good. The only problem with the place is the size. I saw people look in and because it was full, they walked away. We were lucky in that theee was an open table when we got there. Otherwise it would have been a very long wait. Prices are very reasonable.

Delicious, fresh, authentic food cooked by Queen Susie who rocks this place single handed. It's local with no frills and is well worth a visit. Well priced and a few blocks from the beach. Great for breakfast and lunch. Well worth a visit if you are in the area.
Like being in her dining room. Homemade good Korean staples. I had top notch bibimbop.Nothing fancy. Grab a soda from the cooler. Love it. Do not miss.

Susie is fantastic. Do not come here in a rush because she takes her time. She's a beautiful lady with great heart. So please don't rush her. She's the only one here cooking, serving, and cleaning. The wait is worth the time! Menu is on par!.
This place is a small storefront along the train tracks that looks unassuming but delivers a good meal. Solid bibimbop with bulgogi and super pillowy rice. Will go back.
Susie's has fantastic food and it is all run by one person. Would recommend going and getting the pancakes!

A really low-key place with some REALLY good home cooked dishes.  My friend and I got the Bibim Bop with bulgogi and the Spicy Chicken with mixed vegetables.  I will come back again to try some of the other dishes.  It definitely is a long time business that still somewhat of a hidden gem in the Rogers Park neighborhood.
Bulgogi was great and tasted authentic. Susie got my order wrong but I wasn't mad because she was running the whole resultant on her own and food tasted great

The old woman who runs this place is super super nice! The food that we had to go was pretty good but I wouldn't say that it hit the spot exactly. Make sure you stop by and patronize this restaurant because she cares about you just as much as she cares about the food.

I love this place! Susie is so sweet and cute. The food is simple and cheap. Great hole in the wall. Just your basic stuff, nothing fancy in terms of like being vegan or healthy egg whites or anything like that. The cool part is the Korean twist. My first visit I had American breakfast with an omelette, hash browns and toast. It felt like my grandma was making me breakfast. I will try the Korean food next time! Only thing to note is that its cash only. Luckily there is a chase ATM like 1 min away by the family dollar.
This place is a hidden gem. Everything tasted spectacular. I recommend the kimchi omelette!

I live a few blocks away from this little hole in the wall, and I have to say, I'm definitely a big fan of the elderly woman that takes care of this place. The few times that I've been here, I've always seen her by herself.  The food here, I have to say, is always fantastic. It's authentic and very flavorful. I love how well-seasoned the bulgogi is here, and like that it complements their white rice pretty well. Honestly, I feel super privileged to live in an area where I can get Korean food to-go. Give this place a try sometime!

What a surprise to find a place with an authentic Korean taste that's not overpriced in Rogers Park! Don't get me wrong, the fusion places popping up all around Chicago but sometimes (especially when I'm introducing my friends to Korean food), I want some not-overly-sweetened bulgogi or bibimbop with the right veggies and real gochujang. The owner runs the place by herself (cooking, serving & cashier) so expect a wait if you go during popular meal times. Like any other authentic dining experience, this is a hole-in-the-wall so don't expect to be awed by the interior design.

Small breakfast-lunch place run entirely by proprietress, who cooks and serves. Been here twice. Breakfast served all day, so had eggs, sausage and pancakes - all tasty and done right. Other side of menu is Korean dishes. Second time had beef, egg, vegetables, and rice bowl - very good and filling. Daughter had chicken ramen bowl which she liked and said was nicely spiced but not too spicy.

A diner-style Korean restaurant that serves up some damn good comfort food. As you may have read from other reviews here, this entire place is run by this tiny old lady, who does all the cooking and waitressing. She may seem a little grumpy at first but if you talk to her she is actually pretty sweet! A friend and I split a bulgogi bibimbap, and a kimchi bulgogi omelette. I loved the omelette - the amount of bulgogi is generous, and the eggs are so soft and silky. Probably one of my favorite omelettes I've had. The hash on the side is meh but that doesn't really matter. The bibimbap was tasty, too - a bowl of soft and moist rice topped with fresh vegetables and bulgogi. You really can't go wrong with such a classic.
This place is amazing! I got Bi Bim Bop with bulgogi and it was just so delicious.  10/10 would recommend.

FOOD: Great Bulgogi steak Omelette. My first time tasting bulgogi steak. It was a tender and thin cut of meat very well marinated with an ever so slight sweetness. Still dreaming of it. The rice was a great consistency. I can never seem to get my rice that way unless I use a microwaveable rice cooker, which--by the way-- is an invention that has changed my life.  SERVICE: I had to come check out this one-woman show myself after reading the reviews. It's legit. Miss Susie is the chef, waitress, busgirl, and cashier. She was very fast, attentive, and had everyone covered. The place is small, so she has the ability to keep an eye on everything at all times and make sure you have what you need.  LOCATION: Great location, right of the Morse Red Line stop. ATMOSPHERE: No nonsense. Pink pleather chairs and easily wipeable tables. Pretty small place, you couldn't do a cartwheel without knocking something over. But why are you doing cartwheels anyways, weirdo? Definitely will be back to taste the bi bin bop.

This place reminds me of being at home with food being cooked by my Grandma(even though she's Vietnamese). Susie runs this place like her own home kitchen, which just so happens to have tables in it for you to stop by and get some korean breakfast comfort food. She runs everything herself, so there might be a bit of time to get your food, but a little bit of waiting will provide you with large filled omelets, hash browns, rice, and toast, all for super cheap prices. We got here and got a tofu, veggie, and cheese omelet, and a bulgogi omelet, for $7 and $8 respectively. There were enough for leftovers too.  Two points of surprise when coming here are that one, the menu prices are a little outdated and so the dishes may be a dollar higher than listed(meaning that instead of $5-7 for most things they'll be $6-8, not a large deal). Second is that this place is cash-only, but is also untaxed, which almost balances out the outdated prices.  Normally I don't like breakfast foods that much, but I'll take bulgogi and eggs over a waffle any morning.
The place is runned by one woman, she does everything and the food is amazing its only my 1st time but i knw her food is good full of flavor.
Great spot for for the bogie omelette add some kimchi to it I recommend doing that it's amazing enough for three people to eat!! Easy to find its next to social bar in Rogers park.

Susie was an incredibly nice person and made some wonderful homey food. We ordered three dishes, the buchimgae/korean pancakes, bibimbap, and kimchi omelette and all were great for being only $6-7 a dish. On top, Susie rounded our check down, which I couldn't accept. Although definitely tailored to a more american audience, it was more than worth the visit and the wait; will visit again!
Wow! This place blew my socks off. Owned by a super sweet Korean woman. I feel like I just stepped into someone's dining room in Korea and had a home cooked meal.

Susie is the best!! She owns and operates the whole diner by herself! The food is absolutely delicious!!! Order whatever on the menu and you will love it! Bi bim bop is my favorite! Love the egg and bulgogi in it!!! Be patient though, since she takes order, cooks, and serves food all by herself!
One of my favorite breakfast places. I agree the service is slow, but I think it's worth it.

I have to laugh about the people who complain there is only one woman doing all the work there. That is why we love this place. It is part of the atmosphere. And she is amazing.  The food is outstanding. And if you don't want to wait, you might want to make sure the restaurant is empty when you first arrive.

Worst customer service ever. There was only 1 woman doing all the work, so we figured we would wait it out. That would have been fine, but she took over an hour before acknowledging our presence. Before acknowledging our existence, she took the orders of a group that had walked in 45 minutes later than us.

The owner/chef/waitress is a grey-hair Korean lady. The service is kind of slow but it is with the waiting. We were visiting our son at Evanston and stopped here for lunch. We tried to order two Bi Bin Bop, one Omelet with Bulgogi & Kimchee, and Yook Gue Jang (Hot & Spicy Korean soup with beef). She refused our soup order saying it is going to be wasted among three of us.  The food tastes great!

I found this hidden Korean place and decided to try it out  I ordered Yook gye jang which is Korean spicy beef soup. She warned me that it would not be authentic Korean style but I said it's OK. I really enjoyed the soup actually. It was not too strong but came with lots of vegetables and delicate flavor of beef. She frequently check on my table and asked how the food was. She was very kind. Before leaving, I ordered American breakfast style omelet with mustard leaves and mushrooms to take out. I will try it later for supper. I have been to BopNGrill which is kinda nearby but I prefer this place.

I haven't been treated this poorly in a very long time. Considering the current political climate, the prejudice she exuded made me fearful of what is to come election time. My four friends and I were sitting at a table for four. When I ordered she rolled her eyes at me. I didnt mention it to my friends and let it go. We sat patiently waiting for our food. Three other customers came in about 10 minutes later. She took their order and they were served literally within minutes. I felt confused but I was enjoying my company and again let it go. When more time passed I began to feel uneasy but again I chalked it up to the fact that perhaps what the other customers ordered was readily available  and what we ordered, while basic, perhaps wasn't? More time passed. A party of 5 came in. She looked at them and then at us and back again at us. She pointed at our table and said to the party of 5, " you sit here, they have to move!"  (YES. no joke). She looked at us and pointed to a table nearby with 3 chairs ( we were a party of 4) " you sit there! " she coldly commanded. She picked up our waters and moved them to the smaller table. The other party apologized to us and offered to move somewhere else but she said "no. They have to move!". The place was empty aside from my party and theres. I felt like i wanted to cry and yell all at the same time. All i could say to her was" that was so rude". If you are a person of color do not support this business.
Simply put... The highest quality healthy food at an amazing price. Best secret hole in the restraunt. A true gem in the city.

new favorite midday place in Rogers park: Susie's Noon Hour Grill 6930 n glenwood  by the morse l and lifeline theatre. excellent little Korean place with diner-breakfast creations like kimchi and bulgogi omelettes. inexpensive friendly and awesome.

Before my review , I feel as though I should preface that the dish I ordered was by no means a specialty , just chop chae with no meat, so it's possible my experience may have been different had I ordered a signature dish. I feel like that must be the case because I did not enjoy this place at all. My initial difficulty came with ordering over the phone. I ended up having to call 3 times because the woman had difficulty hearing my order and  brusquely hung up on me, no apologies. After getting my food, I don't feel it was worth the ordeal. The meal was all around pretty tasteless , and the tofu they added was on the creepier side of that which I've encountered , being bland , slimy, and rubbery all at the same time. Additionally , rather than give you a full order of your requested dish, over half the box was gill with just plain rice. There was barely any chop chae in there had I wanted it. I won't be returning, as there are just too many better options and this really wasn't even particularly cheap.
Yelp was right on. Great food, low price and slow service. I didn't have any complain for service as it was expected. I'm happy with visit.
She is the cutest! Food takes a minute but is made by hand and with love. Inexpensive too!
Noon Hour is the best one woman show you'll ever attend. The food is bomb! Have at least an hour. It's worth it.

Great find in Rogers Park.  Got the Bi bim bap which was fantastic.  The bulgogi steak in particular was very flavorful and everything mixed well with the red hot sauce.  Prices are cheap so leave a good tip for hard working Susie!

Wonderful food. Small place so you might have to wait a while to be seated. It's a one woman show so the service might not be like your typical restaurant with a full staff. However, the food is way worth the wait.

Delicious! The bulgogi steak is amazing. Be prepared to wait awhile as Susie is doing everything herself- cooking, waiting, serving, and cleaning. Also, it's normal for Susie to not acknowledge you for several minutes. The food is worth the wait though!

I finally had a chance to experience this Rogers Park institution today and I am so glad I did! I love Korean food, crispy hash browns and over easy eggs with a runny yolk and well-cooked white.  Susie delivered on all of that with the eggs and bulgogi steak and hash browns.  My boyfriend loved his omelet made with bulgogi and cheese, served with hash browns.  The bill for two large breakfasts (served with toast) was only $19. Watching Susie prepare the food in the open kitchen and serve the customers at the same time was a treat, too. I will certainly return.

Awesome little diner like place. Bi bim bap is legitimate. But my favorite is the chop chae with bulgogi. Wonderful food, excellent prices, and the amazing Suzy. I would have taken pictures of my food but it didn't last long enough for the camera.
First time here. Meet Suzie the owner, sweetest lady ever. I ordered the Octogawa Scramble and it was amazing!! Highly recommend!!!

We had the Bulgogi Steak, white American Cheese and egg omelette and it was outstanding.  The Bulgogi was delicate and slightly sweet. Bee ordered pancakes and they, also, were delicate and buttery.  We loved it and will absolutely make this a part of our Glenwood Sunday Market routine.

This is my new favorite breakfast spot. I had the kimchi bulgogi omelette and it was to die for. It is amazing to watch Susie make everything... I honestly can't believe she runs the whole place! So so so excited I found this place.

Yes!!!! Why did it take me years to finally come here? I could echo all of the other great reviews, but I'll just say you need to go here. Susie is an amazing cook and makes a mean breakfast and outstanding Korean dishes.

Come for the delicious food. Stay for the extremely blunt responses from Susie. We found this place on Yelp when looking for good brunch spot in Rogers Park. I saw that Susie's had almost five stars and the review highlights looked pretty legit. When we got there we were graced by Susie's infamous "charm". Immediately after saying hello to Susie she responded, "Twenty minutes. Food takes long." The food certainly took a while, and that's because it's only Susie busting her ass on the grill. She's definitely a one-woman powerhouse that creates edible magic.  The food was absolutely delicious. I loved it. There are several options for traditional American omelets, but I wanted something different. I ordered the bulgogi and kimchee omelette. Upon taking the first bite I fell in love with it and Susie. It was one of the best omelets I had in my life. That's saying a lot because I love to eat. I also tried some of the Ramen and it was also amazing. I highly recommend this spot if you want some good brunch.  Before I go here are a few fun Susie quotes: "Sit over there. Don't sit here." "Yes. Go sit down." "No."
Yes, Good food. Hashbrown is amazing. This is the spot for me and my family on a weekend.

This was a fun experience, and the breakfast was great - but I'd recommend going in small groups and having backup plans.  Leave yourself LOTS of time.  The sole proprietor/employee can get very busy, making even simple requests for water difficult to fill.  I had the bulgogi omelette and will definitely return on a relaxed day with a newspaper.

One of Chicago's best authentic Korean spots.  If you love Bi Bim Bap, Chop Chae, and Bulgolgi this is the spot for you.  Every time I come into town, I try and make a stop here.  A small place with excellent food, healthy portions at a very reasonable price.  FYI they only take cash.  Suzie is a sweet lady and will take care of you.  She also has brown rice if you prefer over white rice.  They also serve American breakfast which is really good too.  Can't wait until my next visit!

Real home cook meal! The food is delicious, the portion size is big and the price is cheap. Although it can be slow at a time since there's only one cook when I went there. So if there are too many people around, maybe you should consider finding another place if you are hungry.

The wait is always worth it here. Korean comfort food at its best. So much respect for Susie and the work and love that goes into her scrumptious food. They don't make 'em like Noon Hour Grill anymore.

We come almost every weekend - it is our FAVORITE breakfast/brunch/late lunch spot. Suzie's food is hard to beat, and just watching her do everything by herself is a feat in itself. She is a wonderful cook and Noon Hour is a delightfully quirky little spot. The prices are good, the food is delicious, and this woman is a bad ass.  Go Suzie!
Cute little place, Susie is a hoot.Good flavor, good portions, very inexpensive. The menu is mostly Korean with some American breakfast offerings too.

this place is run by a single older Korean lady and she kicks ass at what she does. I ordered the chap chae and my boyfriend got the bibimbap. Both dishes were delicious and filling and I look forward to coming back.  This place only takes cash so be prepared. It was fairly busy for a small place when we got there as well but we managed to snap a seat.

I walk by this place frequently on my way to the Morse Red Line and read many reviews here on Yelp.  Well, I have one thing to say and that is that I stand with the majority of people who have given this place 5 stars.  Susie does it all and is very sweet, I plan on coming here often and throwing it in to my weekly routine.

Quiet and cosy place. The lady who runs the place cooks every dish to order so it takes a while. The best thing is like you are having a home cooked meal at her table.  The kimchi omelette was a hit, but the other dishes we ordered were just average. The portion sizes are substantial for the price. Might visit again if I am in the neighborhood but won't be seeking it out specifically.

There is something special about a little old lady working alone to cook you Korean style breakfast while playing ACDC over her stereo. How do I feel from the moment I step in this place? Charmed. Susie is awesome. Solid food. Cheap. I can't ask for more.
YES. $10 for a big thing of bibimbop.  Tofu, brown rice and extra gochujang, everytime.  So good.

Susie and her restaurant/diner are about as good as it gets. There are no frills and no fancy here - but there is an abundance of good vibes - Susie is incredible, and her food is delicious. Please stop by, support the neighborhood and local families and business owners - and enjoy one incredible Bi Bim Bop - cooked to perfection! Susie is one incredible chef, business owner and woman - just incredibly lovely - THANK YOU, SUSIE -
I have no idea how this place exists but I'm extremely happy it does.
Great local cheap spot. Flavorful fresh food. Decent prices and portions. The owner is very sweet.

OMG this place is amazing. Been here at least 10 times (right around the corner) and never fails to amaze. Susie is friendly and the fact that she does it ALL herself is incredible. The food is fantastic and consistently so. One of those hidden gems in Chicago!!

My best friend took me here for breakfast one day and it's this little hole in the wall spot that will seriously  become your favorite! Their pancakes are amazing and the lady that works there is so nice. Highly recommend anyone to check it out!

Love this place. I've eaten here several times now. My first visit, I had the Bi Bim Bop... delicious. On my second and all subsequent visits I have enjoyed a dish called Octogawa (sp?) that reminds me of my Japanese grandma's cooking and my childhood.   A tasty mix of rice, egg and ground beef served with a soy sauce,  sugar,  green onion and chili pepper sauce.   I find myself craving this dish often now and I'm glad I live nearby.  I hope I have Susie's energy when I reach her age!

We love Susie's!  You feel like you're eating in Susie's personal kitchen. The Korean pancake is a great starter to share and the bi bim bop is delicious. It's great food at a low cost and we absolutely adore Susie as well--she really cares about her customers and offers fresh, delicious meals.

This place is so low key! Its entrance is in the alley right off the Morse red line stop. It's a 1 woman show. I'm guessing her name is Susie. This isn't anything fancy interior or exterior but if you want good cheap Korean food please go here. You have to love/support these neighborhood gems. Everything I've had here has been solid usually go here for breakfast and get the bulgogi omelette get your day started off right!

Great marinade on the meat.  It's a great, satisfying breakfast and there is no annoying music playing!  It is quiet.  This might make it a little uncomfortable for some, but it's something I cherish when I encounter it.   This is a small, down-home, plain restaurant that serves simple, but delicious all-Korean-American breakfast!  Even my meat and potato father loved it (she buttered his toast).  It may take a bit longer to get your food, but it's worth the wait.

What a gem this place is. With a total of five tables in the restaurant, Susie herself is the greeter, the server, the busser, and the chef! Since she's the one and only worker in the restaurant, be be prepared for a wait, but trust me, it is so so worth it. I enjoyed my breakfast so much that I was tempted to return for dinner.  Susie, you got skills!

First time here. Amazing that this entire place is run by one person. While I was concerned she wouldn't be quick, she only has 5 tables, so obviously she is pacing herself. The food was also so tasty. I eat a lot, so when I ordered the eggs and bulgogi steak I was worried it wouldn't be sufficient. Was I wrong! I'm slumped at my seat writing this because it was fantastic! It came with buttered toast, bottomless coffee, hash browns and jelly. I would love to come by and try other things on the menu.
30 years ago her place was called Pusan (sp?) House. The bibimbap is still delicious - the first I ever had so many years ago and still my favorite.
I love coming here & Susie is the most nicest lady ever! I literally just walk in & she'll just ask Bin Bon Bop? She knows my order by heart already.. Love this place!

I read the reviews here before going... and I don't have any complaints. Susie wasn't able to make the Bi Bim Bap cause she was out of the rice, but that's alright. That happens. No biggie. I ordered bulgogi instead. It was delicious. I respect the hell out of the owner for running this place, it adds to the charm. Great cheap cash only food in a legit atmosphere. I wouldn't say Susie is 'rude' Maybe a little stand offish and not the most outgoing person ever, but that's ok too.

Stopped in for bulgogi and the reviews for the place made me think it'd be a larger, higher end establishment. I was greeted by a wonderful older korean woman who took my order then began cooking. I'm used to bulgogi coming with many little dishes of various side items but this was the beef, some light vegetables and short grain I believe brown rice. I missed all my condiments and sides but my meal was nice. They do not accept credit cards so I'm glad I had cash on hand.

Like eating at Abuelita's, only she is making Korean food instead of Mexican, but it is still homemade and made with love. After a few visits, Susie remembered us and our order and even brought out the gochujang (fermented red chili paste) without me asking. When I had the bi bim bop, she walked by and saw me prodding at it and just chimed in, "Mix it, mix it." It was disarming how genuine and familiar she treated me, which added to the homemade quality of the experience. I always get the bulgogi omelette with kimchi and hash browns. The meat is so flavorful and tender, Guy Fieri would be speechless. Three fluffy eggs and melted cheese complete the yumminess of this huge omelette. I can't get enough and crave it every weekend. The bi bim bop is really tasty too, with fresh ingredients and the same bulgogi as an option.  All this delicious food is prepared by one person. Susie runs the whole place, from taking orders, preparing meals, serving, cashiering, dishes, busing, everything! She has so much energy  and passion, and it really comes through in her cooking. Speaking of Guy Fieri, this is the kind of gem that Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives should highlight. You may have to wait a bit at busier times, but definitely worth it!

i seriously LOVE their food. yes, it is impressive that its run by an old lady who is sassy -- but not all of us like the sassiness, which is why i can't give it five stars. their breakfast is amazing, american or korean. i could rant and rave about how perfect their food is, and can say less than nice things about the owner and her service. the service is slow -- but everyone knows this coming in since its one lady. she won't accommodate you and please don't even bother ordering sides because there is basically no point. she won't let you order them and tell you you're ordering "too much." either way, food is tasty so i don't mind suzy's sassiness from time to time.

Very very bad customer service!!! Old lady running the place has no good manners and right conduct!!! Came in at 9:10 am today and as soon as she saw me she said she's not ready and just keep on saying.... NO... NO... NO. I ask her what time she'll be ready because I can wait but she keeps on saying NO and had the nerve to say I ran the place so I ran my own time. Would not recommend this place to anybody unless you wanna be waited by an old lady with bad manners.
Wow, another great meal at Susie's Noon Hour Grill! She handles everything by herself and really exceeds expectations! What a hidden gem this is!

Apparently they close whenever they want! Today I went looking for some good food and walked in 14* weather just now at 11:00 and lights were off and door was locked I'm very upset if you are suppose to be open your ass better be open!
Best place for breakfast in Roger's Park. Be patient with Suzy as she is a one women show. The wait will be worth it. The Spicy Ramen Soup is the best Hangover medicine I know.
Good food. Sweet lady doing all the work. Ordered the bi bim bop and it was excellent.

The hours for Suzy's Noon Hour Grill are a little confusing. Yelp says they're open at 8AM, but my fella and I dropped in at 8:38 and Suzy was nowhere to be found. We took a walk around the block and came back after 9 and Suzy was there, but the door wasn't open. It was clear that she was prepping for the day, but let us in since we were standing outside the shop. I almost felt guilty being there - like I'd dropped in unannounced and it was an inconvenience...but we pressed on. Fella ordered the bibimbap and I had the yukejang. Since Suzy runs a solo shop, she was judge, jury and executioner for our meal. The bibimbap was lovely - with lots of good fixins, including perfectly marinated bulgogi and an over easy egg. The brown rice was a hearty foundation for the rest of the bowl. The yukejang, while not the most traditional (there was celery in there...) was still tasty. Not too spicy with lots of shredded beef and veggies. The portions were not lacking in the least. A couple things to be aware of: 1. this place is cash only. 2. the pricing is a bit imprecise. Meaning: the entrees we ordered were one price on the menu (say $8.85 and $7.85 or something to that effect...) and the bill was two entrees for $9/pop. Not breaking the bank for sure, and the breakfast was most certainly worth $9 - but I could see how this kind of thing might irk more particular customers.
Don't go expecting a quick meal, go for a delicious change of pace. The food is fantastic, but since Susie is the only employee, it can be a bit slow when it's busy. Worth the wait.

5/5 for food value, very reasonable... most meals under 10 with drink and it's a decent serving. 5/5 for food quality, extremely good, home cooked style authentic cuisine with a twist. 4/5 for cleanliness. Atmosphere is good. It's operated by one person to serve, cook and everything else. Cash only.

I am super bummed to be writing Noon Hour a bad review, but more bummed that I really didn't enjoy my meal here because I was so excited to check it out. Although I cook Korean food regularly on my own, there are just some days where I'm hit with a craving for mama's cooking and I don't want to be the one making it. I tried the bulgogi and kimchi fried rice. Really bad. The overall taste was very bland, the rice was mushy, and there were clumps of white rice that hadn't been thoroughly mixed in with the seasoning. On the plus side, the portions are big, and the bulgogi was pretty well marinated with a nice flavor. I also liked the homey feel of the restaurant...although I was the only customer and even then Susie was a little slow, so I can only imagine what the service is like on a busy day. I do plan on returning because I want so badly to be wrong about this place. I'm hoping my experience was just a fluke, and am willing to risk a couple more sad meals to find a hidden gem on the menu. Next up, bibimbap!

Best bibimbap I've ever had and you can get BROWN RICE which truly takes it to another level. I've only ever ordered that so can't comment on any other items on the menu but other people seem to like the pancakes a lot too.  Susie is incredible, she runs the whole place singlehandedly. Because of this, a couple times I've seen groups come in, seat themselves, then be annoyed she doesn't come to serve you for a few minutes (because she is busy cooking, bussing, and cleaning) and they have walked out. Their loss! Susie will come when she can, and the wait is worth it.  Great coffee too.
Great Breakfast Place meal for two was $12.50. Service was excellent!!!
Love this little place!!!! Amazing!!! If you like Korean, are Korean, or don't know if you may like Korean, go! The woman who owns, runs, and is the entire staff is a gem!

I've lived a block away from this place for 6 months and FINALLY tried.  Why did I wait so long??!?!? This place was delicious.  She's the cook, server, and clean up all in one.  Despite the many roles our food still came out in a timely fashion.  I shall return soon!
Seriously the most delicious bibimbap I've ever had, and I've tried many different bibimbaps. I would recommend it with the Bulgogi. Cant wait to come back and try other items!

Everybody and their morther, grandmother, cousin, and sister raves about Susie and her little Korean diner. I finally came here to try it about a week and a half ago. The restaurant is located right across the street from the L tracks. My girlfriend ordered the bibimbop with bulgolgi, which she thought was really good, but not as good as Yeowoosai. Susie also doesn't serve the bibimbop in a stone bowl to keep it warm sadly. I ordered the kimchi omelette, of which I was not a huge fan. Normally I really like cheese and egg, kimchi and egg, or any of these items separately, but I just was not digging them together for some reason. The cheese and kimchi combo just didn't jive with me. I give Susie mad props for running this place by herself and doing everything from cooking to cleaning to bussing by herself. However, I've heard this place can be slow when busy for the aforementioned reasons. I also think she really needs to accept credit cards because almost every restaurant accepts them and we had to go find an ATM to pay. Overall, Susie's joint is A-OK, which is 3 stars by Yelp standards, but I wouldn't say I'm a fan (4 stars in the Yelp hierarchy).

A must-visit in Rogers Park. Susie runs the show here, single-handedly performing every task, front of house and back of house.  The Korean dishes are incredible. The more American style food is not 5-star, but as long as you watch Susie and understand her importance in this world, you will never leave unhappy.
Excellent food, but don't go if you're in a rush.  Worth it for the bibimbap.  Tasty, generous portion, reasonable price.  Cash only.

The restaurant is located on a super colourful street. Came here for lunch today with a friend at about 1:00PM. When we walked into the place, we were the only customers. Shortly after, a couple other tables walked in to fill up half the restaurant.  Susie runs a 1 man show here. I love it! It makes me feel like I'm being invited into her home to eat some good korean food. Throughout our experience, it seems like she is pretty well known in the neighborhood. We got the bulgogi rice plates (#1 on the lunch meal) for lunch today. She offers you white or brown rice with your meal. The meat is marinated well, but it was a bit too sweet for my taste. It was cooked with a few random vegetables and we didn't have to wait too long! I don't think there were any other drinks offered besides water today?  Not the most fanciest of places, but very comfortable.  End of story: Lunch for 2 = $17. Awesome deal. I'll definitely be back for a quick good lunch if I'm in the area. Seems like they serve breakfast too.

I've had one thing on the menu, 3 or 4 times now. The bulgogi and kimchi omelette. I'm sure other things are good, even fantastic. But I can't imagine anything being more perfect than that omelette and those hash browns. If it ain't broke, don't fix it, and this thing is perfection. This insanely delicious beef, perfect kimchi and some type of magical mystery cheese.  Just stop reading the rave reviews and COME here. Don't care where in the city you are. Just do it.  And someone else mentioned the coffee... I thought it was fine. Great even.

I've been coming here for the last three years, usually with my buddy Whit Whit--we'd meet up Fridays, because those were the only days I didn't have class and she wasn't working at Trader Joe's.  She'd get the Chop Chae, I'd get the Bi Bim Bop and we'd go half on a Korean pancake.  We learned after our first visit to never order the coffee, which are thimble-full mugs of hot, bitter brown-flavored well water.  Me and my friend would yuk it up, catch up, and be totally amazed that Susie was running this ship all by herself.  I'd look around myself curiously at the other patrons, because I was pretty sure I was either going to end up marrying someone from here or the YMCA--that's how much affection I have for it. My last few visits have been a little bit spotty--I've become a huge devotee of the spicy ramen noodles--my buddy Whit told me she saw the seasoning come out of a Maruchan packet.  When I ordered it today, the beef tasted like a MISTAKE--it tasted like I should be afraid of eating it.  I'm sure I'll still return, but the next time I'm going to order hesitantly, no meat darker than a chicken.  Which hurts, because the bulgogi/kimchee omelet is ridiculously good.  The last few visits, the music has also been pretty off the wall--it was opera, then John Williams movie soundtracks, and today it was some hillbilly country that made the questionable meat that much harder to digest.  Also, a friend of mine's boyfriend who is kind of a tool blanked me while we sat a table apart, and he was noticeably rude to Susie while ordering. Not cool, guy.  To sum up, Noon Hour Grill needs--meat that's not terrifying, and to be rid of its low-caliber clientele.

Come for the best breakfast of your life! Allow yourself two hours on a weekend day and an hour during the week. The Korean style breakfast items on the menu keep us coming back that we haven't even tried the traditional ones or lunch yet, but I'm sure it's all great!

My sister has been raving about this places for months, so we finally got to try it.  The place is a little hole-in-the-wall, and is completely amazing!  It was three adults and two 4-year olds, so we were a pretty good group.  Susie rearranged the other people so we could conveniently sit by the window. I ordered the bi bim bap with bulgogi and it totally lived up to my sister's hype!  The beef was flavorful and tender, the veggies fresh and crispy, and the rice not too sticky.  Our friend, Jeff, went to town on the hot sauce - touting it's awesomeness... but my sister and I just stuck with the original taste.  Jeff also let us taste the pancakes, which he claims are the "best pancakes he has ever had" - they were extremely light and fluffy... and had almost a "malted" flavor to them.  Definitely worth getting if you're a pancake fan.  Also, you may wanna check out the korean pancake (particularly the sauce) - the reviews for it are amazing, and the guy at the table next to us nearly licked his plate clean it was so good.   I would highly recommend checking this place out - be prepared to wait for your food since it literally is only Susie doing everything - but the wait is TOTALLY worth it! p.s. Don't forget it's CASH ONLY!

Delicious food. I ordered the bim bop and it was reasonably priced. It was so cute how Susie acted like mom after I got my plate. She walked over to my table and advised me to mix up the food. I didn't, so she walked over again and said '' mix it up plz, it taste better that way''.  Like a child wanting to please mom, I went ahead and followed her directions. Did not regret that move at all as the food was even more tastier.  Although she works alone, I realized that she made sure that her customer were comfortable. This place is reasonably prized and will definitely go back!

Was just introduced to this restaurant by friends that have been talking about it over the past few years. Fantastic food and a wonder to see one lone person doing everything. Had the spicy chicken entree after sharing the Korean pancake.  My son had the Bulgogi and I shared some of my friends' plates. Everything was fresh, spicy and just so amazingly tasty. Will definitely return. p.s. For those knocking the slow service, I'd say you're missing the point. This is like being invited into someone's home and having them cook just for you. Slow down, relax and enjoy a very unique place.

Look, I'm going to break it down for you like I did back in 5th grade at my first dance. Loved it!   The small dive interior may throw some off.  But, just wait until Susie comes out to make you feel like you're at her house.  Oh, and she'll let you know when you're eating your food wrong or ordering wrong.  Some may not like this, but it makes me feel like I'm a guest of hers (those of us who have Asian family members know what I'm talking about).   Yes, service is slower, but come on now.  If I went to your place to eat lunch and rushed you, would you like that??  You can say that you're paying for fast service, but with such low prices, you're paying for the food and the authenticity that comes with it.  I almost feel like we should be honored to be served by someone like Susie who is bringing us into her kitchen. Call me biased because I thought Susie was the cutest thing, but I don't care; I enjoyed every moment of my Bulgogi and Bi Bim Bop, and I will enjoy many more as I frequent there in the future.

This place is SO great.  Bulgogi Omelet w/ Rice everytime.  The little korean lady who owns, cooks and operates this business is adorable, tough and sweet (and a great cook!).   It CAN take awhile to get your order, but that is part of the charm.  This is not a place to go when you are in a rush.  We like to enjoy the wait time with a rousing came of Uno, Crossword Puzzles or scheming.

I could literally eat the Bulgogi here everyday for the rest of my life and die happy. If you're unfamiliar with Korean food, Bulgogi is a total beef and meat connoisseur's dream dish when done well, and here it's as as good as any I've had outside of Seoul. It's also only $8, which is fantastic. Go here and order Bulgogi, you won't regret it.

The food was great. I had the bulgogi and kimchee omelet. It was sooo good except for the cheese. Disgusting processed terrible cheese that only took away from the meal. The rest was delicious. Bacon was very good and the coffee-fantastic! the food I saw on other people's tables looked great also. But I have to take off 2 whole stars for the service. YES-I know she is a one-woman show, but that is why the service is slow and she gets only 3 stars! She is fully capable of hiring a food runner and/or someone to take orders. She makes the coffee, food, wipes down the tables, takes orders, cleans. Literally everything. I totally respect her for that, but it really put a dent in my visit. Unfortunately, as good as the food is, I will not be returning. When I go into a breakfast joint, I'm hungry and I don't have an hour to wait for an omelet.

I'm definitely a fan.   Sometimes I eat there and sometimes I order to go.  It is true that service is slow, but what do you expect when one person does it all.   I guess Susie is a believer in the idea that if you want something done right, you have to do it yourself.  I'm ok with that. Although others may have had different experiences, Susie has never been anything but pleasant and friendly to me, and everyone else whenever I've been there.   We love the omelettes there & she makes great hash-browns.  I'm also a big fan of the bibimbap.  A few others have commented about it being salty, but my experience is the opposite, in fact it is what i get when I want something simple and lightly seasoned.   The chili sauce served on the side is spicy and salty - but that's what condiments are supposed to be... In the end, the food is tasty and cheap and I'm glad to have Noon Hour in the neighborhood.

5 out 7 people ordered Bi Bim Bop -and all loved it! The other two dishes were very tasty, too. Everything tasted home made and fresh.  Service was quick, even it was just one lady. Definitely will be back!

Suzy (Susie?) is the best! I love the blend of  traditional Korean and American breakfast. Honestly, I don't know how she does it. Walk by on any Sunday and the place is packed. The atmosphere is just as great as the food, with clown paintings, Korean children, Rogers Park weirdos and classical music. Her food is very much comfort food and there is not a bad dish in the house. My boyfriend and I don't go to often but she always remembers his order because he gets the same this every time, a chicken and cheese omelet.  Highly recommend anything with Kimchee. My advice, skip the Heartland and go to Noon Hour Grill.

Walking into this small storefront, on this narrow side street, and waiting for a friend at a solitary table, with two other solitary diners around me, I felt like I was in some kind of novel, perhaps by Hemingway. In a quiet little lonely place, with strangers, and a diminutive Asian mom shuffling between the tables and the small kitchen. Some quiet music wafting through the dull lit room. And then came Bonnie! I wanted to introduce my friend to both her first Korean food experience, and hopefully to Bi Bim Bop ($8.50). That's what we ordered. And it was a hit. The menu has a nice limited choice of breakfast and lunch items, and some creative omelets. I would definitely like to sample breakfast sometime. Breakfast at a price breakfast should be. Omelets are all priced around $5-6.00.  The vegetables in the Bi Bim Bop were very fresh. I loved the zucchini. I don't think I've ever had Zucc in my Bi Bim Bop (now there's a good book title!) The Bulgogi was tender and delicious, and the rice at the bottom was brown-nice and nutty. The serving is not huge, but enough that you could take some home like my friend did.  I personally left no Bi, Bim nor Bop in my bowl. It all went to my belly.  Visiting Noon Hour Grill was a very pleasant experience for it simplicity, good value, authentic neighborhood feel and Korean flavors. Take a friend, catch up on things and linger for a bit with Susie. You'll like it.

I used to come here every weekend with my boyfriend. It's homey, no-nonsense, affordable and delicious. I love the kimchee bulgogi fried rice, the bibimbop and the Korean pancake. Susie runs one of the most unique joints in the city, and it's worth a trip. Note to people who have never ventured in before: Susie's a one-woman show, and when she gets busy, it may take a while for her to get to you. Be patient!

We went here for breakfast on a Sunday morning. The reviews I read here are right - Susie is a one-woman show; she serves, cooks, busses, and manages. Because of this, things move very slowly. I do not recommend going here if you are in any kind of rush. The food was unbelievable. I had a mixed vegetable omelet with hash browns and toast. The portions are huge and the prices are low. I definitely want to go back to try some of her lunch/dinner options. The woman knows what she's doing.
Bi Bim Bop w/ bulgogi hit the spot!  Pancakes were also very tasty (and I don't normally order them)...Can't wait to come back and try other things.

LOVE this place and suzy.  used to live in the neighborhood and moved to boystown and missed her so much.  i am now back in rogers park and have already been back 3 times.  love her bi bim bop, her soup is a cure all and the korean pancakes are better than my exes who was korean.

Fantastic food... I can not recommend highly enough. This is one of our favorite breakfast spots. My personal favorite is always the kimchi omelet.  Because the place is very small it can sometimes be crowded especially on the weekends, if so take a small walk and it usually opens up in a few minutes. Well worth the wait.

My only worry is the service; Susie owns the place herself and while she is friendly and attentive, it was very slow. As for the food... The food was amazing. It feels homecooked since it is just Susie and I would definitely come back. I had Chicken Chop Chae and the sauce was great, chicken wasn't over cooked, and I wanted to lick the plate clean. My friend got the Bulgogi and Kimchi Fried Rice. He let me have some and it was the best Kimchi I ever had. Fermented well and had a distinct taste. I hope Susie well in the future!

This little place has become a staple for my girlfriend and me, half because we live around the corner and half because it's unique and delicious. Be prepared to wait a while, as Susie runs the whole place by herself and, if you go on a Sunday, the place is packed. My girlfriend tends to go for the omelets. Susie's happier if you choose rice over hash browns, but choose the hash browns anyway - they're delicious. As are her omelets. Somehow, cheese works with bulgogi and kimchee - I would have never guessed! The veggie omelet has every veggie you could possibly want: broccoli, celery, onion, mushroom, maybe some spinach? I don't know, but it's paired with cheese and it's the best thing. I always go for the bibimbap with bulgogi. It's pretty much everything I'd want over rice - carrots, spinach, zucchini, bean sprouts, a nice stack of bulgogi, and a always perfectly fried egg. The rice might be white or brown depending on Susie's mood, and the chili sauce might be in the bowl or served on the side, but I'm not picky. Maybe I've never come to the shop on one of her bad days, but Susie is delightful. It makes me happy that she's very much a neighborhood figure - she knows people, she adores babies (yes, the babies on the wall - how about those creepy clowns and those precious flowers, too?), she asks about me and my girlfriend if either of us shows up without the other... yeah. This place may not be for everyone, but I'm a fan.

LOVE LOVE this place.  Susie is awesome.  Food is waaaaaaay above average, very very tasty and the price is unbeatable.....seriously. The only thing to understand before you come and enjoy is that you have to be patient with the service because it's literally a one-woman show (cooking, cleaning, greeting, checking-out.....everything).

visited before a northwestern football game.  Did think another customer did have a strange interaction with the owner.  the guy came in and got some weird behavior from the owner and he finally left out of frustration it was strange.  We had great service from the owner.  She was waiter, busser cook and casier.  had a kim chi omeolte and my wife had the bi bom bip whatever and it was delicious.  perfect breakfast.   with this lady could cook me breakfast every morning.  will visit again before northwestern football game.  close to " L "

This place is the best Korean restaurant in the city- and maybe in all the world. Other Korean restaurants have a lot of catching up to do. I'm looking at you, every restaurant in Korea. I don't really understand how you could not like this place. No, actually, I do- you have to sit down and wait a long time for the one woman who runs it (Susie) to briskly take your order, and then wait a long time for her to bring it out to you, and you have to clean up your own table and bus your own dishes and it's cash only and god forbid if there are other people there who are also ordering. But- listen- listen closely to me. If you're one of those... "people" who are "in a hurry" then you can walk your legs down the McDonald's on Clark and Lame, and get a "fast" meal made by some teenagers who probably just finished making out in the freezer (I used to work in fast food). But if you have a lazy afternoon, a twenty dollar bill, and a hankering for some DELICIOUS Korean food, man, you gotta find this place. It will put to shame all the grills that grill at hours other than noon. Bonus points for noticing that on the menus, the image of the clock says "11:59 pm", meaning night, meaning midnight- which is not exactly the noon hour.

I was not put off by the Suze. Loved the bald, Asian babies all over the walls. Waited a long time for coffee -- like 20 amusing minutes --  And why did she assume with her comment, "you wan hash bown not ryze?" that I did?   Was she profiling because I am a tall, fluffy, Irish that I wouldn't be able to hack the healthy? I ordered the special bugogi/kimchee omlette.  It was okay -- except for the shitey processed swiss-flavored cheese -- that was sick.  ORDER EVERYTHING SANS CHEESE! Do it. I coveted the sleepy man's amazing looking soup at the next table. PS -- The Suze shops at The Aldis -- cheap cheap!

Cute little diner with a one-woman crew who makes delicious Korean staples and lovely omelets. My 11 year old daughter tried a bacon omelet and raved about how creamy and smooth it was. My wife had the fried rice and I had the Bi Bim Bop.  The dish was new to me but I'm definitely going to try it again. Everyone left happy.

Slammin Bi Bim Pop!!  Korean style beef with red spicy paste over veggies and rice.  Atop lies a delicious fried egg  The beef is salty but thats why the rice and vegetables are there to balance it out.  Nice n cheap and big helpings.  Plu sSuzy's a sweetheart

Amazing. Cheap. Amazing. You must go here. Your Yelp search has ended here. No, this is not a "kiss your ass" kind of place. Its one amazing lady who makes some cheap, amazing food. Might take a bit, you may wait a bit longer than usual, but dont let that scare you off. If you are used to getting your ass kissed when you go out to eat, then this isnt your palce. If you like amazing food at a cheap price, go here! (IM talking like 6 bucks a person).

Susie seems to not multi-task very well, but it's always nice when the food comes...even if sometimes who you are with is halfway done eating before you get your meal. She's elderly and doing it all...by herself! Knowing that in advance is key! Low expectations on waiting time, but really really great food.

Great atmosphere, fun menu, good prices.   At times the service can be slow (she is a one man show) .  Susie is the cook, waitress and bus boy.  As long as you know its a small unique restaurant, then you can appreciate it for what it is. Also, cash only.  I love it!

I wanted to love this place, but it was only "ok". I made the trek up to Roger Park for it, but don't think it was worth the special trip. I would eat there again if I was in the area already, but not go out of my way there. Maybe I went there with too high an expectation. The food was ok, not amazing. The owner was nice and friendly, so I don't understand some of the gripes about her "rudeness".

I cannot believe what an amazing, wonderful person Suzie is k , now let's get to brass tacks. We are in Roger's Park. A melting pot of cultural and ethnic diversity. Mexican, Indian , and even, yes, I will say it , AMERICAN! cuisine can be interpreted any which way it pleases in this community. OK, so here we go... Let's look at the name of this establishment. "Noon Hour Grill" . I freaking LOVE IT. What is it? I dunno... I was amped to suggest it on Yelp and like 100 + 4-5 star reviewers beat me to the punch. So be it. If you are an open minded diner you will love this place. Consider yourself lucky there are Korean dishes on the menu. Does Suzie care if you like her service or not? I don't care. I reached her twice on two separate occasions. Once for the vegetable pancakes to go, (and I NEVER TAKE STUFF TO GO BECAUSE IT INVARIABLY GETS FUCKED UP BY MOST UNMENTIONABLE establishments). OK round two: Suzie and  I my order, Bi Bim Bop. VEGAN tofu , no egg. No Suzie did not throw a dish on the floor, nor did she turn her back on me. She remembered me from the week before and did my order to go. I never asked her to but she remembered. i told her it was "for here" and I hate to leave restaurants where I order food, and she quickly took a bowl out and assembled , mixed up, and presented BI BimBop as straight up as any Korean Diner I have been to. My point being,; be open minded! You will not be disappointed. Suzie takes 3 buses to make your food, she may be a little cranky, or disorganized, but I can safely say reviewers, does your grandma  run a diner? Thus is America, and Suzie is glad to have the freedom to "do what she does". I am honoured to have had a lovely inexpensive, delightfully seasoned meal, and trust me , I think Korean food is like soul food; every body's grandma knows how to make it, and no body's grandma can make it better. I am glad to have made a new friend today. Thanks , Suzie!

An awesome north-side staple for breakfast and lunch. Workaday restaurants still exist and can be a good time. If you have a taste for the out of the way and offbeat, NoonHour is your huckleberry. The wait and getting teased by Suzy for not eating rice is just part of coming here. You get a home-cooked meal and you talk directly to the only person that works there. She'll be making your food - watch her if you like, she'll be bussing your table, and she'll be chiding you for not being a member of the clean plate club. That sort of interaction is a rare experience unless you're in someone's home.  The dishes vary between just good and delicious - the ramen, bulgogi, korean pancake, bi bim bop, kimchi omelette, they're all tasty. Although I should probably recommend against the kimchi and cheese omelette as american cheese just does not work with kimchi. More experimental than excellent.  Prices are intensely cheap. I always leave a big tip because Suzy seems to work so hard and she runs the place reasonably well.
Mad props to a hard solo owner/worker!  Did I mention her food is delicious!
Delish, friendly, excellent tea + bimbimbop w/bulgolgi.
I love Miss Suzie! !!!! She is a one woman cooking machine. Her breakfast sandwiches are awesome and I crave her Korean pancakes! Yum!

I have no idea how this place manages to garner these positive reviews.  I've been here twice and all I can say is, "If you can't take the heat, get out  of the kitchen."  This place is run by someone who is ill-equipped to operate a place on her own.  She keeps going through tiny little stress-explosions if there are more than two people in the diner.  She's also extremely rude and by "rude," I mean: yelling and screaming as if she's losing it. This is supposedly an endearing quality but I don't go someplace to eat if I also think or know I'll be yelled at or treated brusquely.  Sorry, Susie - I live in a plantation city that already treats people of colour like crap and while your rudeness does not appear to be racially motivated (you were rude to my white friend who, it turns out, is actually someone you know quite well - so perhaps you're just contemptuous of people you are familiar with and their friends: I don't know),  I don't need your bullshit and your blah food. I think some of the reviewers here have deluded themselves into thinking that this is somehow charming, to go somewhere where you get yelled at and it takes an hour or so to get your food - it'snot.  Susie is merely offensive and disorganised.  The food can take ages because she is everything in the place - from cook, to busperson, to waitstaff.  I'm not sure that's particularly good for the business, on a number of different levels.  To make matters worse, she has no discernible system in place to make sure people get their food in the order it was ordered. And, frankly, the food's not that great.  It's Korean for non-Koreans,  and completely unimpressive.   She needs to fold up if she can't take, OMG, the HUGE pressure of, OMG, TWO entire tables that actually need her attention at the same time.

I really wanted to like this place. With all my heart. It seemed like the last bastion of my second half in this windy city. As a Korean-American recently wandering Chicago from Los Angeles (the Mecca of all that is good Korean food, with the exception of Korea), I have been on a desperate search for anything that reminds me a piece of home. Perhaps I just need to stick with what Chicago does best, and for now (although premature) Korean food is not one of them. Don't get me wrong, the Halmonee (grandma) was warm, welcoming and she even let me eat there when it was closing. There really isn't anything wrong about the atmosphere and the homely kitchen look to the place. What I did have a problem with however was the food. I had the Yeukeh Jang and I'm not sure what everyone else has been eating but whatever I ate was not Yeukeh Jang.  By no means is this saying don't go here for food (then again my rating says otherwise), regardless my review probably will have very little effect anyways. To break down the soup... the ingredients in there,I have never seen in my life after a lifetime of eating yeukeh jang. Celery, bell peppers, bulgogi meat? Perhaps I am a bit too harsh, this is not authentic Korean food in the slightest but the rest of the menu did seem a bit promising. She did offer me some bulgogi and kimchi (perhaps she wanted to get rid of it) at no charge and I have to say her bulgogi wasn't too bad. It isn't anything I would kill for but putting myself in the shoes of a hungry lunch hour person, the lunch special would be quite a deal.  The place earns 2 stars solely on the halmonee (grandma) and how warm she made me feel coming to this new town. I would like to give more but honestly...the food is lacking: bland, not spicy, and random ingredients that should not be in traditional dishes. So to sum it up, if you are looking for a good deal on some bulgogi I would recommend the place but if you are looking for authentic Korean food, keep searching. The Bastion is out there somewhere in this town.

Basically, this place is tops. My fiancee had been raving about this place and I finally got to experience the no-frills, one-woman show that is Noon Hour Grill. The food is cheap and plentiful. There's a full breakfast menu of American standards like omelets and pancakes, plus a whole menu of Korean things like bi bim bop and bulgogi. Of course, I ignored the breakfast section and went straight for the bulgogi with kimchi fried rice for $5.95. This is excellent and---I repeat---ONLY $5.95. It's basically like bi bim bop all mixed up already, without the vegetables + kimchi. The fella got the bi bim bop, which might've been a little better but did not come with kimchi. I'd have to order a side of kimchi with it and mix it all up... so it would almost be the same. And my meal was about $1.50 less. I can't complain about anything because basically a Korean version of my grandmother runs this place. You can't complain about Nana being a little slow to cook you a super delicious meal. You just can't. You say thank you and then you try to help her out with the dishes, which is exactly what we did.

As others have said, Noon Hour Grill is a quirky place with good food and a few great dishes - everything has been  consistent and tasty. Love the bi bim bop with bulgogi and have enjoyed some of the other dishes, too. Haven't found anything too light on this menu and everything is always tasty - but definitely somewhere to go when you're hungry and want some good, rich food. The service is what it is - sometimes warm and accommodating and sometimes brusque and borderline rude - but it never keeps us from having a good meal. As long as you know you're going there for the food and not the ambiance or service you'll enjoy it.

Noon Hour Grill makes me incredibly happy. I've been here about three times in the last year, and the food is extremely consistent. My go-to dish is the Bi Bim Bop with Bulgogi, and it never disappoints. The dish consists of Bulgogi, fried egg, carrots, rice, and an assortment of other vegetables. It is quite salty, but that's to be expected with this dish in general. I can't really elaborate much on the dish besides the fact that it is delicious. I went with a group of three friends this last Sunday and we all got the Bi Bim Bop except for one who got the Kimchee omelette. This also looked delicious and was polished off, which I feel is a strong indicator of how good the food actually is. The only reason that I don't give Noon Hour Grill four stars is due to a few things. Granted, Susie is a great host/cook/waitress, but due to the fact that it is a one man (woman) show, it can get a little slow at times. Upon arriving at the restaurant it can take about 10 minutes for her to give you a menu, and then another 10 until she takes your order. It'll be another 10-20 minutes for the food to be prepared, so you're in for quite a wait. There's only about 7-10 tables in the entire restaurant, so seating can be scarce to come by. Also, it's cash only, but she's great about letting you split the bill multiple ways for bigger parties. Also, the restaurant is pretty divey, so don't come here expecting much except for a fresh Korean home-cooked meal.

Small, simple menu with great prices. My favorite is the classic bulgogi BiBimBop. SO GOOD!! The flavors are exactly what they should be and the portion size is amazing. Very very filling. FYI, it is CASH ONLY, but you can fill up without completely emptying your wallet.
definitely a great place to grab a quick, filling lunch.  the beef bulgogi is definitely my favorite.  and the prices can't be beaten.

The place may not look great, but it does have good food. We ordered take-out and got the bulgogi and bibimbop. The bulgogi tasted more like soy sauce that I thought it would, but it was still good. Cash only!
The Bulgogi steak and eggs for brunch is AMAZING. Susie, the only cook and owner, is the cutest/ sweetest old lady, and her service is so genuine.

Wonderful food. Small but charming. Be warned that everything is handled by a sole elderly Korean lady so you might have to wait a bit. That said, the price is surprisingly cheap and the food is fantastic.

I think the owner is homophobic. My partner and I were refused service at this restaurant. She told us we were not allowed to sit at the counter - we could only sit in the back of the restaurant. She did not come to take our order for some time. When we tried to order our food she told us she couldn't make what we wanted, despite us giving her several different options of standard dishes from the menu. She kept on walking away from us in mid-sentence as we tried to order, threw things on the ground and washed dishes instead of taking our order. When we tried to order pancakes she said the griddle wasn't clean so we couldn't order them - then she turned around, cleaned and scraped  the griddle 3 feet away from us, turned back to us and said we still couldn't have pancakes. We couldn't really believe this was happening in 2012 and pretty bewildered, we finally quietly asked each other if we should leave and she interrupted us and said "yes you should leave." We were really shocked - assumed she was this rude to everyone until we asked another customer and he said he has never seen her treat straight customers this way.

Ahhh!  My old stomping ground of Rogers Park. Sadly, I found this place just a month before i left Rogers Park but once I discovered it, I ate there so much I became good friends with the owner!! Actually, I would pass by the place every day for years but just didn't seem like a place worth my time.  However, what a fool I was! The food, as people have mentioned, is delicious...just like how a Korean grandmother would make it...loved the kimchee omelet...and the portions are huge! I really love the owner. I think I'm going to have to make a special trip back just to say hi...and to eat some more of that kimchee omelet!! YUUUM

Noon Hour Grill's 100th review! (Take that, Helen S! :P) This place serves some pretty tasty KBBQ for a steal. It will be a staple in my go-to places in Chicago for cheap meals. The ambiance: It's a dive with some of the kitsch-iest art pieces on the wall! Come see for yourself. This is an awesome place for take-out ... for a date? Look elsewhere! The food: I ordered the Bulgogi Rice Plate for $7 or so. I got a Styrofoam box-full of food in return. It was so much that my jaw literally hung in amazement. It wasn't all rice, either! Half of the massive box was beef. It's quite an impressive feat. How was it, you may ask? It competes with some of the trendier more-expensive places like Jinju in the city. Chicago is not known for Korean BBQ, so it's actually not a big surprise to me that this hole in the wall can produce some of the city's better dishes. The service: Susie (the darling Korean owner/chef) took my order and plated my Bulgogi up in the matter of a couple of minutes. She's really sweet and looks after you. She also seems to have a sense of humor--she looked at me and figured out I wasn't a true Asian and said, "Chopsticks? Or would that be a waste?!?" Haha. That's the hook that will keep me coming back for years (4.5 or so to be exact) to come! TL;DR. Great, CHEAP food. Owner is an asset to the appeal of the restaurant. Definitely must-try.

Came here for brunch with my bf on Sunday. We split the Korean pancakes, and I got the bulgogi/kimchi omelet while he ordered the bibimbap with bulgogi. I thought the Korean pancakes weren't the best, as they were underseasoned and a bit undercooked. Korean pancakes should ideally be crispy on the outside and soft on the inside, but these were soft all the way through. My omelet was pretty good although the flavor combo was strange and unexpected. It did look impressive - when it arrived, the girls at the table next to me were like, "Wow look at her omelet!" The cheese complemented the sweetness of the bulgogi pretty well, so I have to give her props. My bf's bibimbap was also okay, but not the best I've ever had (and it wasn't served in a stone bowl to keep it warm).  Service is good, considering there was only one woman who was both cooking and serving. I think she's the owner and she seemed like a sweetie. This is about as close to homestyle Korean food as you can get, ambiance and all. Overall, 3.5 stars rounding down. It's adequate for toning down my craving for Korean food.

Food: 4 Decor: 2 Service: 4 I came here with my gf for Sunday brunch around noon. It was a bit hard to find since we ended up on the wrong street originally  yelp.com/biz_photos/yD1a… . 1. Korean pancake, 6  yelp.com/biz_photos/yD1a… Okay. 2. Bulgogi and kimchee omelette, 6 Okay. Not a fan of kimchee, but the combination of egg, cheese, and bulgogi was interesting. 3. Bulgogi bibimbop 7.5  yelp.com/biz_photos/yD1a… Good.  Service was good. Menu:  yelp.com/biz_photos/yD1a…

Have I seriously not reviewed this place yet?  I'm here on a weekly basis. Susie makes fun of me because the only two things I ever order are the bulgogi & kimchee omlette or the bi bim bop.  I'm sure everything else on the menu is fantastic, but I can't seem to pull myself away from these things.  As soon as the boyfriend says, "you want to go to Noon Hour?", my mouth instantly starts watering and I can't talk about anything but marinated meat until I satisfy the craving. I tell everyone about this place.  And now I'm telling you.
Boy, if this isn't the best food in the area... The woman behind the counter is quite a character.  Rumors have it that she's homophobic, which I only know through the grapevine.

OMG!!!  AMAZING!!! the inside is not a looker, but do not pass this place up.  I had the bulgogi breakfast with white rice and two eggs over easy and it was to die for.  Best bulgogi I have ever had and I cannot wait to go back to try her Kimchi and bip bim bop :)

Oh my goodness gracious! Suze can throw down -- do NOT pass this place up! Noon Hour Grill is half kitchen, half seating area.  Suze shuffles around at her leisure (you are in her house after all) preparing your order while you sip tea.   Now, I'm not sure if she always serves the kind of tea she served Saturday, but it was a mixture of onion and orange peel, and probably some other stuff.  The ingredients look crazy in the carafe, but it is absolutely delicious on the tongue.  Suze says she thinks it keeps you from getting sick.  I ordered BiBimBop and was stunned into silence and grunting. Honestly, I just didn't want to talk anymore.  The vegetables were perfectly seasoned.  The rice was hot, and the egg on top completed the package.  Her kimchee actually smells the way kimchee is supposed to taste.  Regardless of if that makes sense or not, just know that Suze makes the best kimchee ever! The temptation to order another round was almost too much to bear.  Instead I ordered kimchee and bulgogi omelet to go. It was just ok.  Bottom line: Order BiBimBop!
A great place to eat some reasonably priced Korean breakfast severed by a 1 women army.I have had the Bi Bim Bop and the Bulgogi (pronunciation: [buloi).A great spot off the Mores train stop.

This place is amazing.  Unfortunately, it was out of bulgogi, but everything else we had was superb. It really is like eating in someone's house, and the food is fresh and not oily, which is so refreshing. The lady there is a little spitfire and very nice. I just wished it was open later, but since the lady is the only one operating it, I understand it closing at 7.  I can't wait to return.
I really can't add anything to all the wonderful reviews on here about noon hour grill. The reviews were spot on  - this place is great for wonderful, freshly cooked korean. I ca't wait to go back!

Not too much to add. Susie is great, the homey atmosphere is adorable, etc. I'll just put a finer point on this: You might think you want to order a normal, American, breakfast, or some sort of chicken and rice dish. You do not.  You want something with bulgogi and/or kimchee, with the bulgogi kimchee omelet being the best. The  bi bim bop is also great if you don't want an omelet for some reason.

Greatest gem in Rogers Park! I LOVE THIS PLACE! The food is fresh, tasty, and super cheap. Susie, the owner, runs the restaurant on her own and is so sweet and friendly. I'm a vegetarian and she is always more than happy to switch up recipes to conform to my diet. I've seen her interact with other customers' kids... so cute! It's a very small place so large groups beware. Other than that, an easy 5 stars!
Really wonderful dining experience.  Susie just exudes love and peace.

if you can wait,the food is very good. many years ago when she was on Irving pk road , i took a jarhead to lunch, he whispered i don't eat (inappropriate word ) food after spending years in Asia. he ordered spaghetti and suzy  asked him how many pork chops he wanted with it. .after lunch he commented this is like eating at grandmothers

Just here to reinforce everything people've said here. Small, slow diner, everything done by one woman. She takes a minute to get to you, but once you're in, you're in. My brother had the Bulgogi Kimchee Omelet ($5.75), and I had one of the 'new' items, an Octogawa Scramble with rice ($5.95). Both were delicious, and easily more food than you ought to even eat. Frankly, I shouldn't have finished the scramble, and I went into food coma. Pretty sure there''s more in there than a Chipotle burrito. Those and two cups of coffee came to $15.85. Definitely a new favorite, I'll go out of my way for this place.

I moved to Rogers Park 5 months ago and have already been to Noon Hour Grill way more times than I can count, including visits on consecutive days. The bulgogi bibimbap is my favorite.  I also recommend both kinds of pancakes -- the savory Korean kind and the birthday-cake-like (in a good way) American variety. Enjoy the bizarre, spare decor -- including clown paintings and photographs of Tibetan children -- and don't forget to tip Susie well!

Love this place already!  Definitely worth checking out.  I'm ashamed to admit I haven't been here yet given that I live within a block and a half of it (seriously)...but it's great.  The woman running this place is super sweet.  I had vegetable fried rice and bulgogi, both of which were fantastic and huge portions for the small price tag. Like other reviewers have said, service can be a bit slow given that it is one woman doing all the work!  She appears to take care of one table at a time, but once she gets to you, she's incredibly friendly and gracious.  I'll be back very soon!

YES! The lady running the joint is a superstar. She is really great i have gotten the cheese and onion omlette which comes with rice and toast, and it was great! Just what i needed. The only thing that was sub par....... and not that big of a deal but ........what the heck is up with playing Dr. Phil, or Maurry, or Montel Williams in the morning? I didn't want to make a fuss about it but what a way to try and enjoy your eggs right?  Thank you for being so awesome lady behind the counter...

2 things to make it short...:  Best breakfast ever and best service ever!!!  Food is excellent and you can get from kimchee to pancakes. My favorite is the bulgogi steak, best one ever, you should try it, You can get it with rice or pancakes and even in omelets. Cheap and a lot of food. *Note: She likes it when you finish all your plate. Agree with others reviews, Susie is just Awesome, she does everything by herself, and I mean everything from cleaning to cooking. The atmosphere is nice, when you walk in is like you are in you grandparents place. And Susie really fells like your Grandma, she is a nice lady and very friendly... Its always nice to eat here and have a conversation with her. Its like being at home.. Keep it up!!!!

OK, for us Rogers Park folks, this place combines the best: a mix of old and young, all body shapes, slightly left of center, in both politics and dress; and awesome food; both the Korean dishes and the American style, plus awesome omelets; worth getting up early for!

Awesome. Cheap and delicious korean food, brought to you by a little Korean woman who you watch make your entire meal, from washing dishes to scooping rice, to frying up meat/eggs/etc. We went for lunch on a weekday, and it was still pretty crowded (by crowded, I mean 5 of the 6 tables were taken). It's a little slow, which is expected because it's just the one cute little lady. But wait patiently, and you will receive a giant plate or bowl of food that will make you happy. I got a soup dish (yukgaejung, I think that's how you spell it) which is basically a nice spicy beef stew. At Noon Hour Grill, she really loads it up with veggies and a nice amount of meat. So tasty. My dining companions got the more standard bibimbop, which is so great, and the bulgogi, which was a huge amount of food. I'll definitely be back!

I had heard about this place from a foodie neighbor but failed twice to eat there because I chose Monday for a visit and it's closed.  After over a year of not trying friends came into town and we tried it for breakfast.  They so loved it we went two days in a row. I love it when a place makes you smile when you go to it as this place does  The bonus here is that Susie herself makes you smile.  When you enter you've arrived at Susie's Zen space.  Time slows down and you must let Susie take care of you and charm you. At times she might be playing Classical music or a PBS TV show.  Anyway, she's all there is.  Moving from grill to tables to do what she does.  It's almost like sitting at someones Grandma's very large kitchen.   The food is fresh and delicious. You are unlikely to go hungry and who doesn't love the option of having breakfast any time of the day?  Much has been written here so I won't occupy more space but after trying Susie's last night for some Bi Bin Bop (with bulgogi) I couldn't leave it alone, it's my new local obsession. Susie is a gem and her business a treasure in my funky Rogers Park neighborhood. Why don't you come see your adopted Korean Grandma?

I have not been able to stop thinking about the food at this place since I left.  I have walked by this place a million times and never once considered walking into the unassuming looking joint....man have I missed out on years of good food.   Thank you Yelpers for forcing me to give this place a chance.
