Susan is slow moving, but it is very much worth the wait.  She takes very good care of each customer, and went out of her way to take care of  my 2 year old during our time there. (approximately 2 hours- there were 3 other tables eating other than us)   The Kimchee omelet sounded so intriguing I just had to give it a try.  This cheesy, salty, spicy mix of eggs, kimchee, sausage, and cheese is odd sounding but a pairing made in heaven.  It was very satisfying and the price was a bargain all the way.  The portions were large, and the food was fresh and filled with love.   It will not be a quick meal, but it will be one of the better breakfast experiences you will have.

This is my new favorite breakfast place!!  Susie, is great and very friendly.  She really gives you more than enough for what you pay.  I ordered the Denver Omelet and was stuffed with a lot of leftovers. Its very small and she does everything by herself, so don't go if you don't have time to wait.  But it's worth the wait.  I love that it's walking distance from my house!! Also CASH ONLY!

I love this woman. My first visit here, I ordered the kimchi fried rice. And how much does she give me? So much, the rice is literally spilling off the plate! The bulgogi she makes is top class, and is clearly made as if she is your grandmother. I think she was somewhat shocked that I finished the plate. That'll show her to challenge my stomach! Affordable, delicious, and local. What more can you ask for?

Delicious food made to order. Generous portions. The owner/chef, Susie, does everything from wiping down tables to slicing veggies to asking how your day is going. I am so happy a place like this can exist in our world today. Three cheers to Susie!

OH MY GOD YES!  That was the thought going through my head as I took my first bite of my Kimchi omelet... that's right a kimchi omelet.  I would have never thought those two flavors to go together but it is like heaven and earth good!   Usually when you hear the word fusion it is a dirty word of gross bad asian/latin/whatever else hack of a restaurant, but this is the most unpretentious  fusion place in the world.  As said it is a one women show, she takes your order, makes sure you are getting enough food like a good mother/grandmother, then cooks it.  The combination are  strange for diner fair yet so tasty.  The Kimchi omelet was more of a scramble but it was layered with American cheese, sausage, and of course kimchi.  The portion was huge and totally worth every penny and more.   Another amazing element is the decor of the place floral painting next to clowns sitting on a rainbow, next to a tiger painting.  Just amazing and awesome.  This is everything I want out of a restaurant and will make it a stop any time I'm visiting Chicago!

This place is one of a kind because of the aforetold one-woman-show. I had to introduce myself to Susie on the way out and she gave me two cookies she happened to have on the counter, one for me and one for my boyfriend who was already outside. This place is truly amazing because of the one person behind it all. The boyfriend and I got there and the tables were full but we were in luck since two tables were about to pay. Susie quickly cleared and cleaned a table and we were seated within two minutes. She came to take our orders and embedded them sans papier ou stylo. This woman is talented in all things food service. Our food arrived and didn't take as long as I expected (probably about 15 minutes) and there was A LOT. First she brought our toast, pre-buttered at the counter, as a sort of breakfast appetizer, we decided. Then came the main attractions, two scrambled eggs, hashbrowns, and bulgogi for me and the kimchee/bulgogi omelet with hashbrowns for the boyfriend.  Everything was great. I'd never had korean food before and noon hour made me want to try much more of it. The bulgogi is so so good, as mentioned by many other yelpers. I had to take some food home because it was too much for me to eat in one sitting. That evening, of course I made a bulgogi sandwich with my leftovers and it was, of course, just as good, maybe even better the second, colder, time around. Also, our bill was 12 bucks and some change. You can't beat this place. It's an experience to see Susie hard at work and how the customers talk to her like family, the food is delicious, and everything is super cheap. What's not to love?
Hidden gem of rogers park. Great and very reasonably priced breakfast, lunches (and early dinner). Check it out, you won't be disappointed.

Excellent! I tried the bulgogi and the Korean pancakes (first time I've ever had Korean food).  It was very very good and the service was great.  But I have a side story- I ran into Susie a year ago in Dominicks before I ever tried Noon Hour Grill.  I was looking over some meat and trying to work out a recipe-.  She randomly started to talk to me over the meat and was so sweet and helpful- telling me where to go to get certain food items and why a certain kind was better than another.  I never forgot how nice and helpful this random woman was to me in the store that day- that sometimes people can just be nice.  Imagine my surprise when I ran into her at Noon Hour?  I know she didn't remember me but I remembered her and her kindness.  Well that translates to her food.  Bit of a wait but home cooking.  Try it, you won't be sorry.

I am going to make this short and sweet. THEE BEST BREAKFAST KOREAN FUSION RESTAURANT! Susie the owner is such a sweetheart. It is like my grandmother was cooking for me and knew what i liked.  The menu has regular breakfast foods and some items are korean fusion breakfast meals.  There are not enough words in the english dictionary to describe how good the food is. Hands down my go to breakfast spot if i were in the area. Cash only so make sure you have some, because the Chase next door raped me on fees.
Super Home Cooked Korean and Breakfast.  Recommend: Bee Bim Bop, Korean Pancakes. Susie, the owner does everything on her own so like others have stated, it can be slow but worth the wait.

Note: My review is based upon trying the Hot Peppered Chicken and not the more traditional Korean dishes.  Also I was mistold by a friend that there would be Soon Doo Boo here so there is a possibility of bias upon the disappointment of not getting Soon Doo Boo.  It could also be possibly that for some reason I am not as big of a fan on certain types of my own ethnicity's foods... kind of sad. The first feel you get right off the bat from this place is: run down diner.  There's nothing wrong with that in my books (these type of places a lot of times are gems).  They have a breakfast menu (similar to the foods you would find at an American diner along with some fusion styles I am tempted to both pass and try on (Kimchee Omelet... Ooo & uhhh at the same time) ) which they serve all day & a menu with Korean dishes (you can see the choices of the menu in the pics section).  The place was sparsely lit, and had classical music (cool).  The only person working there was a tiny old Korean lady.  My company selected the bi bim bap and the bulgogi & kimchee fried rice.  I went with the hot peppered chicken.   When the lady served me the hot peppered chicken she warned me: be careful it's hot.  I took one bite and said... eh no it isn't, just a little spicy.  Then I realize I didn't try it with the jalapeno pepper that was on top of the whole dish sliced in half.  I took a portion of that and ate it with the rest and yeah... now I got the warning.  The vegetables (cabbage, celery, onions, carrots) were crisp and not overcooked.  The chicken was well cooked.  The spices and marinade complimented the dish overall. The dish overall felt like I dish I could get made for me at home (I realize maybe that's the reason why it gets such the great ratings compared to my subaverage rating).  Btw, yes they make Korean food, but no they will not give you banchan (extra dishes of food to compliment your meal).  The food is served in more the diner style. The Korean dishes my friends bought were very legitimate Korean dishes (What's that suppose to mean?!  I'll explain.)  The bi bim bap... it's served the way it should be in my opinion.  Not bashing Crisp, Gyu Kaku, or Del Seoul, but the large amounts of vegetables and meat they serve with the rice is exactly how bi bim bap should be served and this place does that... yeah the old Korean lady who cooks all the food herself gets it!  I tried a bite of my other friend's bulgogi and kimchee fried rice... same thing.  Generous ratio of meat to the rice and the rice has a great crispiness to it (Like the type of kimchee fried rice you make after eating a Korean BBQ).  The two dishes were made just the way I always remember them to be back home when my mom, grandma, or some other female relative made them (I'm not being sexist, just the old patriarchal mindset of my previous family generations setting into play).      If you're Korean (or Asian... ah hells every ethnicity why not), the food you eat here will definitely have the "it was made like you are use to have it at home" feel.  And considering the area (right by Loyola University) surrounded by students, this is great comfort food that's easy and cheap to obtain.  Check it out-

One of the most unsuspecting spots in Chicago. A few months ago, we went here with some of my boyfriends friends and were we in for a treat- I haven't stopped thinking about this place since we left!  Walking by the storefront, you would never take a second look into the small, 5 or so table dining room, but we did end up taking a second look and I'm glad we did. We went there on a Saturday morning for breakfast and everything our table had was delicious. I really suggest any of the omelets- amazing! All the food is made with love and it really shows in the dishes. The owner/chef/hostess does everything herself, and since it's a one man show, the wait I'm assuming could get a little long but its worth it. If ever in the Rogers Park area- try this place out!

Kudos. A small little Korean restaurant with good food. I ordered the Bi Bim Bop and split a Korean pancake with my friend. Both were pretty good. The sweet little owner was really nice, and it sounds like she does it all by herself! I hope she does well.

This is officially my Sunday afternoon spot! Its Sunday nite and i'm thinking of making it my Monday morning joint 2morrow! Once you dine here U R gonna find yourself pheining 4 Susies food. I'm working my way through the menu...and not even graciously. Her Bulgogi is melt in ur mouth insanity aka DA BOMB! The omeletes are huge and the price is right. Kimchee or Tufu omelete $4.50 w/hashbrowns rice and toast incl? ( where they do that at? haha! ) My friend is always absolutely "so starving" but 3 Sundays ago I made him just w8 (and w8 u will if its crowded) none the less,  he is now officially hooked as well! Her price points are incredible, so you can't help but tip like a baller 4 the 1 woman show. Last Sunday I actually asked her if she needed a server or a busser/dishwasher 4 the weekends? She said "I work alone, ppl in my way make me nervous..i had a Korean boy come in 1 day..i screamed @ him so bad.. he not come back!!"    -- Ok susie I pheel you.. i'll still clean my own table when i come in and w8 patiently cause the food is always fresh, delicious and cheap!

Because I'm an idiot, I went to the Noon Hour on a regular basis for about three years before I tried anything but the breakfast dishes (usually an omelet).  Slightly less of an idiot now, I recently have had a couple of the Korean dishes on the menu.  SO GOOD. Seriously, the bulgogi haunts my dreams. Pros: The menu is small but has plenty of variety. The food is delicious. Suzy is a really nice woman who will remember you when you come back to eat a second time. The prices are super low (probably because there are no employees to pay). Cons: When the place is busy (Sat and Sun mornings) you can wait forever for a table.  If it is extremely busy, I don't bother waiting because the times I have eaten here when there's a full house part of my order has come out wrong.  I think if Suzy could hire someone just for a couple of hours on the weekends to pour coffee and do the dishes I would make this my regular weekend breakfast place.  Oh, and it's cash only - there's a Chase around the corner.
Suzie (the owner)is the best and her food is too! I love the Bulgogi so much I haven't tried anything else. The portions are absolutly huge as well.

Awesome one woman show!  Bulgogi is really tasty.  Don't go in there and expect the fastest service (especially when it's busy).  She cooks, cleans, waits and wipes tables, and is the cashier...so cut her some slack.

Note: You DO NOT come for service or ambiance. Noon Hour Grill is about one thing: simple, delicious food. The prices are great, and the Bi Bim Bop here can stand up to anywhere else in the city. Just make sure to call ahead if you're in a hurry, as there is only one chef/waiter, so if more than a few people show up at once, you'll have to wait. But it's well worth it.

American breakfast Korean food all in one joint? Don't mind if I do! The owner of this place is the sweetest lady--and she does this all by herself! So if you get here and there are a few people already waiting, know that it may be a while before you start eating. It will be well worth it though. Bring you cash and tip generously! The American b'fast food is pretty much your regular type greasy spoon options--if fresher-tasting than most diners--but what really intrigues me are the few items that seem to incorporate both elements of the menu, like the ginger, garlic and carrot omelette. So good! I'm no connoisseur of Korean food, but for Rogers Park, this may be as good as it gets in that direction, and I just love the general vibe.

I keeping seeing lots of rave reviews about the bi bim bop but it was okay. Growing up with eating lots of it in NYC/NJ, perhaps my standards are different so if you're Korean like me, I would bring my own kochujang(hot pepper paste) and maybe sesame oil. There's nothing wrong with the ingredients itself but  it was lacking sesame oil and the hot pepper paste was not your standard paste. It wasn't ultra smooth and sweet but vinegary and kind of chunky with red pepper flakes so I ended up adding a touch of sugar and bring my own nori seasoning. Other than that, the owner was nice and expect up to an hour wait during peak times even if you are seated because it's a one woman show.

A great (somewhat incongruous) neighborhood joint for grabbing some bi bim bop on Saturday mornings, especially now that they repaved all the sidewalks in the neighborhood. Susie, the proprietor, is as nice as can be. Once, she asked me if I would like some kim chi with my bi bim bop. I responded by telling her that I was not a big fan. This was followed by a period of awkward silence.
Food here is amazing! You must get rice with your omelet! Susie is so sweet make sure to treat her right. Keep in mind this is a cash only joint, bring your dollar bills.

I love korean food. But as a student on a budget, Korean BBQ is hella expensive. If I want something Korean thats delicious and super cheap, Noon Hour is the best! I take all my friends here. It is run by this nice korean woman and she is a one woman-show. Yes, it takes a bit of a wait and yes, she only takes cash but she's super friendly and charming. Also, 6.50 for a coffee, toast, rice, and a bulgogi kimchee tofu omelette? SCORE! The servings are huge too! I love to eat, but I can barely finish my plate, but she kept telling me to eat. It was delicious and I did not want her to feel bad so I graciously consumed the entire thing. Other highlights on the menu are the korean pancake and the bim bim bap. It's a must of Rogers Park!

This diner is around the corner of the Morse Ave stop. Love Korean food and eat it a few times a year. Decided to try Noon Hour for lunch. It was a semi-busy Saturday. Be prepared to wait and wait. This delightful Korean lady does her own cooking and only will attend to one table at a time. She will not give you any attention, including a menu, until it is your turn. After 30 minutes, it was finally our turn, she took our order and the cooking began. The Korean pancake was wonderful. The bulgogi not so great. For me it was too sweet. No pancheon were given out. How can a  Korean restaurant not serve pancheon(multiple delicious side dishes)! My husband asked for kimchee and was ignored. This was a very long 2 hour lunch of mostly sitting around and not eating.

Total hole in the wall, decor-wise.  I can't believe I love it as I do but the carrot/ginger/American (yes, American?!?) cheese omelet is sooooooo good!  And, Susie is so cute - she runs the place herself and so, it may take a bit to get all you need but she is on top of coffee refills, etc as she can be.  The bulgogi is delicious as is the spicy sauce that accompanies the omelets and while I have not had it yet, friends rave about the bi bim  bop.  I feel comforted when I go here despite the weird pink chairs and old wallpaper!

I wish I got up before 2PM every day, and I just might rearrange my schedule to eat here. I mean a little Korean lady, Susie I believe, takes your order and personally cooks you a delicious breakfast, for not much money at that. My four person family got filled up for less than $20. I can't wait to go back for the Bi Bim Bap everyone keeps talking about, it makes me look forward to winter for some reason.

Neighborhood best kept secret---the Noon Hour Grill is a one woman show. She does EVERYTHING by herself and that is why the Kimchee Omelet!!!! is only $6.  Giger, Carrot Omelet $5. Soooo good. Portions are huge, fresh and coffee is delicious. The Noon Hour Grill is very busy on Sunday so be prepared to wait for a table (I recommend bringing a book or a newspaper) but that is expected the wait is much worth it because the food is AMAZING!!!

Move over Crisp cuz you've got competition! This place literally looks like a run down diner located right next to the train tracks - you wouldnt even be able to tell they served korean food here if you didn't read the menu.  We ordered take out and got two orders of the bulgogi bim bim bops (marinated beef with spinach, carrots, bean sprouts, zucchini and a fried egg over rice).  They came out looking picture perfect and for less than $8 a bowl.  There was a ton of greatly flavored meat piled on top and the veggies were all super fresh and lightly sauteed.  They also had a lot of the other korean restaurant staples on the menu (korean pancake, jap chae, bulgogi fried rice) for super cheap prices.  I think I've definitely found my new korean fast food spot!

I had the beef bulgogi with white rice, it was fantastic and the price was very cheap. Susie is a friendly lady that cooks and runs the show. The place was so calm and peaceful with the classical music station playing, I didn't want to leave once my meal was done.

I'm not sure I've ever seen a kimchi and bulgogi omelette up for offer before, so of course we had to order that... in addition to the ginger, garlic, and carrot one everyone here's been raving about. Two omelettes are more than enough for three people, which makes breakfast for 3 cost about $10.  I'm sorry, let me clarify: an extremely yummy and unique breakfast.  Both omelettes were sloppy-looking and chock-full of goodies - big slices of bulgogi and chunks of cabbage, cheese strings dangling everywhere when an omelette was cut.  So much shredded carrot in the veggie one that it was practically orange.  Each one came with toast and jelly and hash browns. My two qualms with the place: they use American cheese and give Smuckers grape jelly with the toast.  That's it.  And they're not really so much qualms because, come on, $4 or less per person. There is one woman who cooks, takes orders, refills coffee, takes money, and everything in between.  She never slows down.  Knowing how hard it is to feed even two hungry mouths (I'm not sure I've ever done it without screwing up somehow or having to ask for help), I can only imagine how hard it would be to feed fifteen.  And on top of that, to have the food be as tasty as it is?  Amazing.

LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.  Don't expect a lot of flash of a restaurant, as NHG is home-style Korean food, all done by a one-woman show. I checked this place out for lunch today (I finally made it over while they were open...), and was very happy I did.  I got bulgogi (over white rice), and a side of kimchi. The bulgogi was REALLY good, lots of flavor and it came mixed with some veggies. Kimchi was plenty for a marginal cost. I still have half of my meal saved for later. Kam sa ham ni da! The owner was so polite and sweet, enough for me to leave tip on take-out. I'm coming back to try the spicy pork/chicken meals! Mmm!
Totally lives up to the hype.  Had the bulgogi and kimchi omelet (I question the American cheese in there, but will just remember to order without next time).  Not a work of art, but oh-so-delicious.

I love my coffee. And, I love bulgogi. I've been eating it for over 35 years now (way before the current Korean craze). And, let me tell you, no one makes better bulgogi than Susie. No one. Unfortunately, many places make much better coffee... and in the morning I just NEED coffee... and lots of it. Susie's coffee is the pits... and the refills come rarely. Since she uses little cups to begin with, this means that a coffee junkie like myself leaves under caffeinated. Susie, please, PLEASE, upgrade your coffee service. Use a better grade; give us bigger cups!. If you do, then I will come in and have my bulgogi and eggs almost daily! But, not until then.....

O.M.G. I don't want to admit this, but I only just went here in the last 2 months or so.  If you knew where I live and have been here, you would mock me.   I saw it open, but at first, there was nothing posted in the window.  No menu, no clue what exactly was going on inside.  I also tend to walk along the other side of the train tracks.   But the boyfriend moved in and we happened along the other side of the tracks.  Saw a menu in the window.  The prices?  Are insanely low.  We thought, " Hm.  Cheap, sounds interesting, we should go sometime."  Then I saw all of the Yelp reviews.  And I hung my head in shame.   How could a 4.5 star place be so close to my house and I haven't been there?  Oh the indignity!! So we went.  And have been there three times in about as many months.  It would have been more, but we are trying to pinch pennies.  Get ANYTHING with the bulgogi in it.  I had never had bulgogi, I suspect that I am now ruined for life.  I suspect that no other restaurant makes it as good.   What are you waiting for?  GO!!  It's not even a full block from the Morse el stop you fool!

Amazing Food!  One of the great perks of living in rogers park is this place! I always get the food to go,  so i don't have to deal with the strange looks i would get due to the unusual moans i give out while eating this food.  its just that good, i don't know what else to say other than if you haven't eaten here you could not possibly understand how good the bulgogi is..

One of RoPa's great little finds, great breakfast at an even better price.  Susie has some traditional american breakfast fare along with Korean fare on the Menu.  Menu is small, but not on flavor.  Limited hours, and like another review said-- not a place to go if you are in a hurry as the food is made to order.

Excellent food.  Very very nice proprietor, but as a one woman show  sometimes you need to bring patience, as she's great at multitasking but there are a lot of tasks for one person at a restaurant.  If it's less then four parties then expect normal wait times. But her cooking is excellent.  Her hash browns fit the top of the standard by which I measure all hashbrowns everywhere. The bulgogi is amazing. I need to say that again: The bulgogi is amazing. I've never had her bi bam bop but it looks perfect (generally been in a bugogi and eggs kick lately). My roommate really liked the tofu scramble.  She's got great coffee.  Next time I go I'm totally going to try the special pancakes - I bet they rock.  Although I hesitate to make this comparison out of not wanting to minimize Susie (the proprietor)  and her awesomeness, if anyone remembers Jim's Grill, her cooking is totally on par or better. And she's got interesting taste in paintings.  Tip her well as she is the embodiment of all things good in restaurants.  The bulgogi is amazing.

Noon Hour Grill is a Rogers Park favorite of mine. Susie (the owner/cook/waitress all rolled into one) is a lovely person, but service is slow. It's not a place to go to when you're in a hurry. If you love Korean food or just breakfast food and aren't in a rush, try Noon Hour Grill. The Ginger, Garlic & Carrot Omelet (yes, it sounds weird, but is wonderful) with a side of bulgogi is my favorite for breakfast. For lunch, you can't beat her bi-bim-bop.  If you're looking for plentiful hearty, hot, VERY fresh food served in a relaxed diner-like atmosphere, Noon Hour Grill just might be your spot.

Great for a hearty meal when you don't want anything fancy. Suzy is a one-woman show and does everything great! She waits, cooks and buses, and the food always comes out hot and delicious! Everything is good, from her simple American breakfast items to her Bulgogi and Kimchee Fried Rice - soo good! Love Suzy's!

What a great and amazing find! I was headed up to RP this Saturday with friends for another event and decided to check out the place for breakfast after finding it on here. It is on Glenwood half a block down when you get off the train. Took a second to find it. Susie, the only woman working the place, made an amazing bulgogi and kimchee omelette for me. The idea sounded odd on paper, but was heaven! Cute place. Great food. Unique spot. I will be back soon!

Jeeeeezus, I LOVE SUSIE.  Can I just say it again???  She took my Chicago Reader away because it was yesterdays, & gave me todays paper (it was The Times or something) & that was pretty amusing.   She's like my mom or something, except she's half as tall & is a way better cook (sorry, Ma)  I DEVOURED my bi bim bop.  Usually it's enough for 2 meals...but it just tasted extra delicious.  She wouldn't accept my tip...Whatttt?!  I figure since she does ALL the work, she'd appreciate it, but that's Susie.  What a gal.
The kind of place thats everybody's secret. Tip big.
Delicious. Everything thus place offers is delicious and home made. The bi bim bop is the best in the city. Nummers.
Tasty, cheap food and a cozy environment make this place a must-try if you're in the neighborhood. Susie keeps some interesting omelets on the menu -- and so far, so good. Closes early.

Susie makes the best bi-bim-bops in Chicago. I don't know what she does to the bulgogi- but it is incredible. It is a little sweet and melts in your mouth. You can even get a bulgogi omelet! Susie used to be on Irving Park road, but the CTA demolished the building when they did the Brown Line renovation. When that wrecking ball came, a little piece of me died along with the building.  In the year that Suzie was gone, a friend and went to almost every Korean restaurant in Chicago to fill the bi-bim-bop void in our souls. I can confidently say that nothing came close to Susie's. We missed the meat the most, and also her special homemade hot sauce. Its a one woman operation, so things are a bit slow, and its not exactly the classiest decor. However, it doesn't matter at all because the food is delicious. Bring cash. Also, do the right thing and clean your table for her when you're done. You would do the same for your mother, and eating at Susie's feels like eating at your mom's kitchen. Except your mom's kitchen is a storefront in Rogers Park, and you have to pay when you're done. Come here often before she decides to retire. You'll miss it- I know I did.

The food is really good, really cheap, but not really fast.  Easily the best Asian joint in RP, but that doesn't say much.   Even though the service is on the slower side, the resto is extremely hospitable.  Since it's cold out, visitors can expect complimentary hot tea, which I'm sure is never the same twice since Susie makes it herself. Great place to eat on a budget, but be warned that it's cash only.

Being a Rogers Park native, I couldn't wait to head over to the Noon Hour Grill for breakfast. I was sadly disappointed.  The owner/chef/server is adorable but it took forever to get everything and anything.  From water, to the omelet, to the check.  The price though, can't be beat. 2 3 egg omelets, with hasbrowns and toast for ten bucks.  I might give it one more shot but, I doubt it. I am bummed. :(

Okay, okay, how can I not give a place five stars after they almost gave me a free meal? After handing Susie my debit card she said "No, no just cash." I proceeded to dig in my bag for cash and she seemed embarrassed that I was counting my change to pay her and almost didn't let me pay! Never thought that would happen in Chicago. How can she not expect me to pay her when her TV reception is bad and she peels potatoes with a knife? T-T  Food was fine and the portions were generous. Somehow I finished it all in one sitting... The only thing I'm confused about is drinks. Do they have a drink menu? Are other drinks available besides water? Do you just have to ask?...

If you like small hole in the wall diners then this is your place. Susie is one amazing lady, you can miss her adorable charm. My favorite dish there has to be the Spicy Chicken, make sure you have her make it HOT. It has a nice kick to it and comes with a pitcher of water too. I wonder if she would make it into an omelet for me. If hot isn't your thing then order anything else it's all good.  Enjoy!!!!
Great food, service, and prices!  Susie not only serves your table but also cooks your food.  If you don't see it on the menu she'll be happy whatever she can for you.  I love the bulgogi omelet.

This was the first place I ate at in my first time in Chicago :] My boyfriend is a huge fan and he took me here for lunch :] We both got a korean pancake and the bi bim bop with brown rice :] Lots of spicy red sauce was added and I downed it all super fast. The menu is interesting.. omelettes w/ kimchi?! YUM! the pancake wasn't like normal panjeon but actually like a REAL pancake with veggies in it :] Either way, delish :]

Fabulous breakfast had the Denver omelet to go. Susie was a very sweet little lady. When I got home the food was to die for big chunks of ham, green peppers and onions seasoned just right and the cheese was excellent I am used to american cheese in my omelette's but the white cheese she used was even better. Overall great food for very cheap. I will definitely be going back. Gotta love "The ROG"!

The minute I stepped into Noon Hour Grill,I knew that I had definitly made the right choice.My nose could pick up faint smells of kim chi,but my mind was set on ordering the classic Bi Bim Bop.I admit,I was skeptical at first about how great the food might be due to the fact that there was only one little old lady manning the store front diner by herself.But,I couldn't have been more wrong.I ordered the bi bim bop and was amazed that a dish so simple could be so delicious!My friend ordered a bulgogi omelet and equally loved his dish.I barely made a dent in my bowl and almost felt like Suzy was disappointed in me for not finishing it.However,she was incredibly nice and packed my food to-go.Between myself and my friend,our bill was less that $20!I'm so glad that I found this hidden gem in my neighborhood and plan on coming back for some of Suzy's amazing Bi Bim Bop.

Suzy disappeared for a little bit stupid "L" , My friend and I went on a Bi Bim Bap tour of Chicago, looking for something as Delicious as the Noon Hour Grill!!!!  We needed our Bi Bim Baps!  Countless restaurants we ate at, and nothing, nothing as good as Suzy prepares! There are no little Kim Chi dishes at Suzy's But she makes the MOST Delicious in Chicago! I can assure you all that.

had the bulgogi bibim bop, so my review is based on this.  when i went i was the only customer there.  i ordered and waited for my food.  i tried to strike up a conversation with the owner, but she wasn't very responsive.  this is unfortunate since many of the other reviewers speak so highly of her.  i told her i was really looking forward to trying the food, still no response besides "oh".  the bibim bop was good, not mind blowing, but the portion was great.  i finished off the whole bowl and was very full.  it's great there is a korean-diner fusion option in this neighborhood if only to expose more people to different types of food. i wish i could've experienced the great personality that others mentioned, but she was a dud for me.  i almost feel guilty for not giving her a sparkling review, because i honestly WANT her to do well, but i won't be back.  i trust that the rest of you (4+ star reviewers) will keep her in business :)

Sometimes you need to get out of your comfort zone.  My company gives us Good Friday off ? WTF....so I decide to try something radically different from my normal eating habits.  Korean it is. After some Yelp searching I decide that the best way to experience Korean is by going home.  In this case, 'home' is Susie's home.  Noon Hour Grill may technically be a restaurant, but for all intents and purpose, you might as well knock on an aging Korean woman's front door and ask her to cook you some delicious classic Korean dishes that she learned from her grandmother.  I have never eaten 'real' Korean food like this, but it was very tasty.  Since I don't have a basis for comparison, I won't bother trying, but if this is Korean food? Count me in. Let me know if you're going...I'll join you. PS Absolutely NO credit cards.  Cash only.

If you're on a tight budget, come here, get all your food groups in with the bi bim bap, and you won't have to eat anything again for the next 24 hours... as long as you empty your bowl. Still as amazing as ever.

Susie! Can I put you in my pocket and take you home?!?! You're soOOo adorable! Thank you so much for making me such a tasty Bulgogi and Kimchee Omelet. It was definitely a nice change from the standard meat, cheese, and veggie omelet. It came with hash browns, a side of toast, and tea which was really nice since I was hanging out for a while reading my book.  Susie is such a sweetheart. The omelet was huge and I ate most of it, but it looked like I hurt her feelings when I told her I didn't want to take it home. (I thought it wouldn't make good leftovers). I felt like a bad kid that didn't 'clean' her plate! But I vehemently told her everything was great and that I will surely come back. I almost wanted to hug her. =) The place is cute as well. It's small with an open kitchen and it almost feels like you are sitting in her kitchen at home. Susie is amazing! She does everything from taking orders, to cooking the food, and clearing the table... by herself! Pretty nimble for an older lady!  Good food, great prices and amazing service! Definitely a must try.

Eat here now! Outstanding food just like your Korean grandmother makes! So what if I'm just  some white boy? The bi bim bop with bulgolgi (or tofu for my wife) is beyond excellent. It's amazing to see Susie at work. Mid 60s and running tables and the kitchen without breaking a sweat!  As a bonus, for 2 bi bim bops with tea, tax and a generous tip.....$20 flat!
Great food.  A friend and I were looking for a place to eat and by the suggestion of yelp, we went here.  Had the Bi Bim Bop which was great.  Plenty of food.  Susie was very nice .
LOVED the kimchee and bulgogi fried rice!  The serving was huge!  There wasn't too much bulgogi, but that's alright.  It was delicious and the kimchi was perfectly sour!
Excellent Bi Bim Bop. This dish is fresh, filling and delicious and priced reasonably. Susie's got her cooking down to a science. She has got it going on. Don't miss out on this great little place.

Susie is great! She's a one-woman efficiency machine. Had the tasty bibimbop and my wife had the eggs and bacon. While the eggs were good, the bbb was even better according to the wife. Will be back many times.

Bulgogi in my omelet?  Yes sireee! This quirky diner serves up Korean and American fare for breakfast, and mostly Korean fare for lunch.  They (by "they" it's Susie) have a Wednesday lunch special as well.   Cool thing on their menu?  "Anything you want" ... "market price" ... If she has the ingredients, she'll make it.  I assume. ? :] There's also "to go" specials on a morning breakfast sandwich and coffee ($5ish). Their hours change seasonally:  in the summer they're open until 8, in the Winter until 4pm, but there's a note on the menu that you can "call ahead" for to go dinner?   My bulgogi omelet (I added mushrooms as well) was quite fantastic....  perfect in fact.  I'm not into really eggy omelets, and this wasn't.  Everything we had was good... As far as cleanliness goes, you'd have a hard time finding diner-ish place that's as clean as this.  I imagine Susie goes through and cleans the place every night...  And no Yelpers, they do NOT take credit cards...so ignore that at the top (unless this review swings the field to be "no" where it should be)!!  I trusted other yelpers and showed up with no cash, only to find I had to take a 10 minute roundtrip to the nearest ATM in 12 degree weather... Not fun Yelpers.  Reasonable prices though. This is a one woman operation, so you might have to wait on that coffee refill while she takes care of making food for 2 other tables, etc.

this is my choice for bi bim bop that just don't stop.  susie rocks.  hard.  we all love her.  we worship her.  we clear tables for her.  we protect her from the unseemly characters who might stumble into this el-track-side cafe.  we leave her big tips.  we even offer to take orders for her when things get too busy for her little adorable smiling self.  come here.  support here.  join us here.

I came here a few weeks ago and tried their Korean breakfast!  Definitely a unique experience that I haven't tried before.  I got the bulgolgi omelette.  It was pretty tasty, though there wasn't enough egg-to-bulgolgi ratio.  Definitely needed more egg to offset the sweet marinade of the bulgolgi.  I did like how they used real hash browns (instead of home fries that some places call "hash browns"), though the hash browns were a little too heavy on the butter.   Service isn't fast because it's a one-woman show, who serves as cook / waitress / cleaner.  She's a cute, old Korean lady, and it feels like you're eating in her open kitchen.

What a perfect place to have Sunday breakfast! My boyfriend and I had been meaning to come here for months and we finally made it there on his Birthday. I don't believe in eating food out, that is easily made in your home. If you come here, don't be silly and order some over easy eggs and hash browns. Go out on a limb, and order an omelette with fresh garlic and/or ginger in it. Great choice for garlic lovers. Service is friendly and fast. Everything is decently priced. We will be back to try the bi bim bop and kimchee omelette, as we live in the neighborhood and walk by this place every day.
Susie is pretty amazing. Everything I've had on the menu is completely fresh, and tastes home-cooked. Impossible to beat when all you want is great food and conversation over breakfast.

I went to this restaurant based on the reviews I read and it sure did not disappoint.  It satisfied my korean and breakfast cravings all in one go! I ordered the bulgogi and kimchee omlette with rice and it definitely hit the spot for me.  My boyfriend had the bi bim bop and that too was delicious.  The only disappointment was the korean pancake and that I have to say I was not a fan of...have had better elsewhere...but otherwise, everything we ate was uber yummy.  The auntie, who runs the one woman show,  was so friendly and the customers were definitely all repeats as they knew her by her first name and was chatting up a storm with her.  If you are in the mood for koreanfied brunch or just regular breakfast grub, this is the spot.

I'm a notoriously picky eater...  But the smells coming out of this place cannot be ignored.  The food is amazing and it seems there's nothing Suzie won't do to accommodate a customer.   You've got to try this place out for yourself!

You get a diner feel when you walk in, but after sitting down, I felt like I went to my aunt's house for lunch.  Susie is the hostess/waitress/cook and she is so sweet and friendly.       While she was preparing the bi bim bop, she would ask from the kitchen if my friend wanted the eggs well done or over easy.  As for my bulgogi kim chee fried rice, she would mention that it was little spicy.  I really felt like I was being taken care of by my auntie!     The Bi Bim Bop smelled so good and it was so healthy with brown rice, zucchini, egg, tofu, bean sprouts, and spinach.  I actually liked the bi bim bop here over the H mart food court and San Soo Gab san restaurant.  Bulgogi Kim Chee fried rice was not amazingly spectacular, but I was satisfied.  Both dishes were filling and we were perfectly content.         I would definitely go back for the BBB!

This cafe seems to be run by one woman named Susie who cooks and takes your order. I will have to try the Korean food next time I go here. I got the 2 eggs, toast and hash browns and there was some lovely hot sauce.  I hear that the bacon was a bit to fatty.   The experience we had here was sort of bizarre because there was an old very drunk man who Susie was trying to shoo out but ended up serving. In case we doubted that the Doors were playing on the radio, he announced it to everyone in the tiny restaurant. He pulled out all the groceries from his bag and put them on he table, including a bag with a carton of cracked eggs that were sort of gathering at the bottom. They argued about whether he was drunk for a while. He maintained that he wasn't, until he pulled out a bottle of gin from his bag and tried to drink it. But by the time he came up and told me I had exquisite ankles and my girlfriend had a magnificent ass, a guy who was dining there helped with his removal. Susie finally locked the door because he kept trying to come back to his table. I will definitely be back to try the Korean pancakes or omelet with garlic, ginger and carrot. And hope that the other diners stay at their own table.

You know a place is special when your coffee comes to you in Branson, MO. mugs! A very cute little spot that more people should try.  Went  for lunch today at noon and there was nobody inside except Susie.   I had the Bulgogi and Kimchee stir fry, which was a huge plate of delicious food with some amazing spicy chutney stuff.  When it was brought out to our table, Susie said, "Hot!"  It was, but not unbearable.  My lunch companion had a plate of Bulgogi and liked it a lot. We will definately be going back.  I know I'll be coming by in the morning for a "To-GO" breakfast special.

This little hidden gem in Rogers Park has the best Bi Bim Bap in the city. A small Korean diner, quiet and unpretentious has GREAT kimchee...and I love my kimchee. Susie runs this place single handedly and her home style cooked breakfasts are terrific. Healthy and delicious food, this is a great  little place off the beaten track; I will be back!

the lifeline theatre shares this block of the glenwood arts district, but if you want to see a real, non-staged, one-woman show, take a lunch at susie's noon hour grill. or breakfast. dinner on select days. call first. bulgogi sangwiches. where else can you get bulgogi sangwiches? i don't know. korean spaghetti. where else can you get korean spaghetti? your grandma's house? if you're korean? i don't know. if you're not into that, well check out the rest of the menu. susie makes it all. she cleans it all. she waits all the tables, opens, closes; she's a strong lady. i've never been there when there's a full house, but if so, i'd expect a patient wait. it's worth your time. one thing, she really takes care of her peeps. so much so, they take care of her. i've seen regulars bus others' vacated tables, just cuz they want to help. there's a nice affection going on here.  they may one day fictionalize susie's plight at the lifeline, but in the meantime get the real deal (what's with the rhyming?) from a standout of the endangered order. she balked at extinction when ousted from her former location on irving, under the brown line station; life doesn't often offer such second chances. apparently, she makes those, too.

Haven't tried the Korean food here yet but for $5 you can get a delicious standard breakfast, eggs, pancakes and two bacon or sausage. Fantastic! After hearing great things about her food, I will definitely be back for more.
